sub_points: Papillary renal cell carcinoma (RCC) often with foamy macrophages; often with higher-grade cytology, including more prominent nucleoli; AMACR and CK7 diffuse and strongly positive

Clinically Relevant Pathologic Features.text: Gross appearanceMost WTs, other than those with diffuse blastemal pattern, well circumscribedIt differentiates them radiologically and grossly from more aggressive pediatric tumors like rhabdoid tumor of kidney, as well as most mesoblastic nephromas
sub_points: Most WTs, other than those with diffuse blastemal pattern, well circumscribedIt differentiates them radiologically and grossly from more aggressive pediatric tumors like rhabdoid tumor of kidney, as well as most mesoblastic nephromas
It differentiates them radiologically and grossly from more aggressive pediatric tumors like rhabdoid tumor of kidney, as well as most mesoblastic nephromas

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Reporting of presence or absence of anaplasia is essential component of surgical pathology report on WTDiffuse anaplasia, when present, usually apparent in most tumor sections; presence at any margin, or in extrarenal sites, considered diffuse anaplasia; presence in random biopsy (although rarely performed) also considered diffuse anaplasia
sub_points: Diffuse anaplasia, when present, usually apparent in most tumor sections; presence at any margin, or in extrarenal sites, considered diffuse anaplasia; presence in random biopsy (although rarely performed) also considered diffuse anaplasia

Terminology.text: Congenital mesoblastic nephroma (CMN)
Spindle cell neoplasm of kidney, composed of myofibroblasts
Subtypes/variants: Classic, cellular, and mixed

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Classic CMN typically diploid; cellular CMNs often with aneuploidy of chromosomes 11, 8, and 17
Cellular variant has t(12;15)(p13;q25) chromosomal translocation resulting inETV6-NTRK3gene fusionSame translocation as seen in infantile fibrosarcoma
sub_points: Same translocation as seen in infantile fibrosarcoma

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Occasional association of CMN with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome

Clinical Issues.text: Most common renal tumor of infancy
Majority cured with surgery and have excellent outcome
Increased risk of local recurrence with incomplete excision

Macroscopic.text: Solitary, unilateral; classic CMN with whorled or trabeculated, gray-white cut surface and indistinct tumor-kidney interface; cellular CMN often fleshy with circumscribed edges

Microscopic.text: Classic variant (24% of cases): Intersecting bundles of spindle cells with minimal atypia and infrequent mitoses
Cellular variant (66%): Pushing border, dense cellularity, mitoses, and sarcomatous appearance
Mixed (10-20%): Shows combination of both histologic patterns

Definitions.text: Most common renal neoplasm of infancy with spindle cell features, mimicking fibromatosis or infantile fibrosarcoma

Genetic Features.text: Classic CMN typically diploid; cellular CMNs often with aneuploidy of chromosomes 11, 8, and 17

Cellular variant with t(12;15)(p13;q25) chromosomal translocation resulting inETV6-NTRK3gene fusionSame translocation as seen in infantile fibrosarcoma; also recently reported in secretory carcinomas of breast
sub_points: Same translocation as seen in infantile fibrosarcoma; also recently reported in secretory carcinomas of breast

Genetic Features.text: No gene fusions demonstrated in mixed pattern
Occasional association of CMN with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome

Presentation.text: Most common renal tumor in first 3 months of life; > 90% occur in 1st year of life
Presents as abdominal mass; may be associated with polyhydramnios, premature delivery, and nonimmune hydrops
Hypertension (due to renin production by entrapped renal elements) may be present

Surgical approaches.text: Because of marked infiltrative nature of classic type, partial nephrectomy often not feasible option in many cases

Prognosis.text: Majority cured with surgery with excellent outcomeRecurrences and metastases in ~ 5-10% of patients; risk factors for recurrence include incomplete excision, stage III or higher presentation, and involvement of intrarenal or sinus vessels
sub_points: Recurrences and metastases in ~ 5-10% of patients; risk factors for recurrence include incomplete excision, stage III or higher presentation, and involvement of intrarenal or sinus vessels

General Features.text: Solitary, unilateral; classic CMN with whorled or trabeculated, gray-white cut surface and indistinct tumor-kidney interface; cellular CMN often fleshy with circumscribed edges
Cysts, hemorrhage, and necrosis common, with no prognostic significance
Tend to arise centrally within kidney and often involving renal sinus extensively

Histologic Features.text: Classic type (24% of cases)Shows intersecting bundles of spindle cells with minimal atypia and infrequent mitoses and resembles fibromatosisTumor infiltrates extensively into adjacent renal parenchyma and renal sinus structuresDysplastic renal tubules and islands of cartilage are often seen trapped within tumor
sub_points: Shows intersecting bundles of spindle cells with minimal atypia and infrequent mitoses and resembles fibromatosis
Tumor infiltrates extensively into adjacent renal parenchyma and renal sinus structures
Dysplastic renal tubules and islands of cartilage are often seen trapped within tumor

Histologic Features.text: Cellular variant (66%)Shows pushing borders, dense cellularity, and numerous mitoses; morphologically, similar to infantile fibrosarcoma
sub_points: Shows pushing borders, dense cellularity, and numerous mitoses; morphologically, similar to infantile fibrosarcoma

Histologic Features.text: Mixed (10-20%): Shows combination of both patterns

Metanephric Stromal Tumor.text: May mimic classic CMN; usually does not present within 1st year of life; margins not as infiltrative as in classic CMN
Shows dysmorphic vessels, juxtaglomerular hyperplasia, and concentric spindle cell proliferation around vessels and tubules, and usually CD34(+) stroma

Clear Cell Sarcoma of Kidney.text: May mimic cellular CMN; cellular variant of CMN lacks chicken-wire vascular pattern of clear cell sarcoma of kidney (CCSK)
Presence of other patterns of CCSK (e.g., myxoid, sclerosing, epithelioid, palisading)

Wilms Tumor.text: Most difficult differential, particularly posttherapy Wilms with stromal-type residual tumor
Wilms tumor (WT) very rare in infants, especially those < 6 months old
Extensive necrosis, as in posttherapy WT, and rhabdomyomatous differentiation not features of CMN
WT with compressed pseudocapsule in contrast to extensively infiltrating borders in CMN

Rhabdoid Tumor of Kidney.text: Occasionally CMN may have unusually prominent nucleoli, raising suspicion of rhabdoid tumor of kidney (RTK)Immunohistochemical stain for SNF5(INI1) (positive nuclear staining in CMN and absent staining in RTK) diagnostic
sub_points: Immunohistochemical stain for SNF5(INI1) (positive nuclear staining in CMN and absent staining in RTK) diagnostic

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Vast majority of patients < 1 year old, at which age other pediatric renal tumors less common
Surgical margins, especially medial margin, need careful evaluation

Terminology.text: Clear cell sarcoma of kidney (CCSK)
Uncommon malignant renal neoplasm of childhood of uncertain cell of origin with aggressive clinical behavior

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: 2 recurrent, likely mutually exclusive, genetic aberrations recently describedInternal tandem duplication inBCOR(BCL6 corepressor) geneFusion ofYWHAE(tyrosine 3-monooxygenase/tryptophan 5-monooxygenase activation protein, epsilon) andNUTM2B/E(NUT family member 2B)
sub_points: Internal tandem duplication inBCOR(BCL6 corepressor) gene
Fusion ofYWHAE(tyrosine 3-monooxygenase/tryptophan 5-monooxygenase activation protein, epsilon) andNUTM2B/E(NUT family member 2B)

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Nonrandom translocation t(10;17) and deletion 14q also described

Clinical Issues.text: Treatment with doxorubicin shown to improve outcome
Ipsilateral renal hilar lymph nodes most common site at presentation
Bones are most common sites of recurrence
Presence of tumor necrosis only histological prognostic variable

Microscopic.text: Diagnosis primarily based on histologic criteria
No diagnostic immunohistochemical or molecular features available at present
Morphologic hallmark: Evenly distributed network of vascular septa, with branching chicken wire pattern

Ancillary Tests.text: No specific stains available for CCSK

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Blastema predominant Wilms tumor; mesoblastic nephroma; primitive neuroectodermal tumor; rhabdoid tumor of kidney

Definitions.text: Uncommon malignant renal neoplasm of childhood of uncertain histogenesis with aggressive clinical behavior

Molecular Genetics.text: 2 recurrent, likely mutually exclusive, genetic aberrations recently describedInternal tandem duplication inBCOR(BCL6 corepressor) gene; associated with epithelial-to-mesenchymal transitionFusion ofYWHAE(tyrosine 3-monooxygenase/tryptophan 5-monooxygenase activation protein, epsilon) andNUTM2B/E(NUT family member 2B); fusion involved in cell cycle progressionFusion identical to endometrial stromal sarcoma
sub_points: Internal tandem duplication inBCOR(BCL6 corepressor) gene; associated with epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition

Fusion ofYWHAE(tyrosine 3-monooxygenase/tryptophan 5-monooxygenase activation protein, epsilon) andNUTM2B/E(NUT family member 2B); fusion involved in cell cycle progressionFusion identical to endometrial stromal sarcoma
Fusion identical to endometrial stromal sarcoma

Molecular Genetics.text: Nonrandom translocation t(10;17) and deletion 14q also described17p13 is locus ofp53gene, butp53alterations seen only in anaplastic CCSK
sub_points: 17p13 is locus ofp53gene, butp53alterations seen only in anaplastic CCSK

Epidemiology.text: ~ 20 new cases/year in USA; comprise 3% of childhood renal tumors; M:F = 2:1
2 months to 14 years old; peak incidence: 2-3 years old; congenital cases and rare cases in adults reported

Presentation.text: Large single renal mass, hematuria and hypertension

Treatment.text: Combined therapeutic options, including nephrectomy, adjuvant chemotherapy with doxorubicin, dactinomycin, and vincristine (NWTS 4 regimen), and tumor bed radiation

Prognosis.text: Aggressive clinical course; lymph nodes most common metastatic site at presentation, and bones followed by lung and retroperitoneum, most common sites of recurrence

Independent prognostic factors for survivalTreatment with doxorubicin; stage 1 disease (98% overall survival); improved outcome in patients 2-4 years old; tumor necrosis (adverse factor for survival; only histological prognostic variable)
sub_points: Treatment with doxorubicin; stage 1 disease (98% overall survival); improved outcome in patients 2-4 years old; tumor necrosis (adverse factor for survival; only histological prognostic variable)

General Features.text: Unicentric, well-circumscribed renal mass; mean diameter: 11.3 cm (range: 2.3-24 cm)
Often homogeneous, solid, tan-gray, glistening, gelatinous cut surface; often with cystic areas and foci of hemorrhage and necrosis

Microscopic Features.text: Diagnosis primarily based on histologic criteria; no specific immunohistochemical features available at present

Classic pattern, present in 90% tumors at least focallyAlmost evenly distributed network of vascular septa, with branching chicken wire pattern, similar to myxoid liposarcoma and oligodendrogliomaSepta divide tumor into nests and cords of polygonal cells with indistinct cell borders, nuclei showing finely granular chromatin and inconspicuous nucleoliCells often surrounded by pale, mucopolysaccharide material, often creating illusion of clear cytoplasmNecrosis: Only histologic factor of adverse prognosisEntrapped renal tubules along periphery
sub_points: Almost evenly distributed network of vascular septa, with branching chicken wire pattern, similar to myxoid liposarcoma and oligodendroglioma
Septa divide tumor into nests and cords of polygonal cells with indistinct cell borders, nuclei showing finely granular chromatin and inconspicuous nucleoli
Cells often surrounded by pale, mucopolysaccharide material, often creating illusion of clear cytoplasm
Necrosis: Only histologic factor of adverse prognosis
Entrapped renal tubules along periphery

Microscopic Features.text: Variant patterns (listed in order of observed frequency)Myxoid, sclerosing, cellular, epithelioid trabecular, palisading/spindle cell/storiform, anaplastic (with nuclear hyperchromasia and gigantism, and atypical mitoses)
sub_points: Myxoid, sclerosing, cellular, epithelioid trabecular, palisading/spindle cell/storiform, anaplastic (with nuclear hyperchromasia and gigantism, and atypical mitoses)

Microscopic Features.text: Histologic variants do not affect prognosis

Immunohistochemistry.text: IHC primarily useful for excluding other renal tumors; no specific stains available
Vimentin and Bcl-2 (+); pax-2/pax-8 some tumors (+); epithelial markers, CD99 and WT1(-)
p53 consistently positive in anaplastic tumors only

Blastema Predominant Wilms Tumor.text: Chromatin pattern coarse with molding; WT1(+)

Congenital Mesoblastic Nephroma, Plump C.text: Spindled and polygonal cells, prominent nucleoli; actin (+)

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Diagnosis primarily based on histologic criteria, hallmark being evenly distributed chicken wire network of vascular septa
Attention to overall morphology and immunohistochemical stains usually help in excluding differential diagnoses

Terminology.text: Malignant rhabdoid tumor of kidney (RTK)
Highly malignant pediatric renal tumor with very poor prognosis and genetic abnormalities ofhSNF5/INI1/SMARCB1tumor suppressor gene

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Biallelic inactivation of gene, located at 22q11.2, consistent feature of RTK
Occasional RTK with intact SMARCB1 expression harbor mutations inSMARCA4/BRG1gene

Clinical Issues.text: Mean age of presentation: Around 1 yr old
Predominantly affects younger children; 80% < 2 yr old, 60% < 1 yr old
Overwhelming majority of stage IV renal tumors in 1st 7 months of life are RTK
High tumor stage at presentation

Macroscopic.text: Well circumscribed and nonencapsulated
Foci of hemorrhage and necrosis

Microscopic.text: Sheets of monotonous, loosely cohesive, large ovoid-to-polygonal cells, with high nuclear grade
Characteristic cytologic features: Vesicular chromatin, prominent eosinophilic nucleoli, and intracytoplasmic hyaline, pink inclusion, at least in some cells

Ancillary Tests.text: Loss of immunostaining for SNF5 (INI1) considered specificReliable surrogate marker ofhSNF5/INI1/SMARCB1gene deletion or inactivating mutations
sub_points: Reliable surrogate marker ofhSNF5/INI1/SMARCB1gene deletion or inactivating mutations

Definitions.text: Highly malignant pediatric renal tumor with poor prognosis, and genetic abnormalities ofhSNF5/INI1/SMARCB1tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 22

HSNF5/INI1/SMARCB1Tumor Suppressor Gene.text: Biallelic inactivation of gene, located at 22q11.2 consistent feature of RTK; usually associated with deletion of 1 copy with mutation in remaining copyGene believed to be important for chromatin remodeling
sub_points: Gene believed to be important for chromatin remodeling

HSNF5/INI1/SMARCB1Tumor Suppressor Gene.text: Children with concurrent RTK and atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumor of CNS often harbor germline mutations in ﻿HSNF5/INI1/SMARCB1gene

SMARCA4/BRG1Gene.text: Occasional rhabdoid tumors with intact SMARCB1 expression harbor mutations inSMARCA4/BRG1gene

Epidemiology.text: Comprise 2% of pediatric renal tumors; M:F = 1.5:1
Mean age of presentation around 1 yr; 80% < 2 yrs old, 60% < 1 yr old; virtually nonexistent after 5 yrs of age
RTKs constitute most stage IV renal tumors in first 7 months of life

Site.text: Originally described in kidney; similar tumors later recognized in extrarenal sites, including CNS (atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumor) and soft tissue

Presentation.text: Abdominal mass most common mode of presentation; hematuria &/or fever other common symptoms; rarely hypercalcemiaSome tumors produce parathyroid hormone-related protein or prostaglandin E2
sub_points: Some tumors produce parathyroid hormone-related protein or prostaglandin E2

Presentation.text: > 75% present with stage III, IV, or V disease; metastases to lung, abdomen, liver, brain, and bone frequent

Tumors in kidney, CNS, or soft tissue may occur sporadically or as part of rhabdoid tumor predisposition syndrome (1/3 of RTK cases)Germline mutations ofhSNF5/INI1/SMARCB1common in patients with apparent sporadic tumors as well as in familial rhabdoid tumor predisposition syndrome
sub_points: Germline mutations ofhSNF5/INI1/SMARCB1common in patients with apparent sporadic tumors as well as in familial rhabdoid tumor predisposition syndrome

Treatment.text: Surgery, chemotherapy, radiotherapy in combination with autologous stem cell transplantation with best results

Prognosis.text: Extremely poor prognosis with mortality rate > 80% within 2 yrs of diagnosis
Predictors of poorer prognosis include: younger age, higher tumor stage, and presence of CNS lesions

General Features.text: Typically, large tumors with ill-defined borders, often with areas of hemorrhage and necrosis in cut surface

Size.text: Range, 3-17 cm in diameter (mean: 9.6 cm), sometimes replacing entire kidney

Histologic Features.text: Sheets of monotonous loosely cohesive large, ovoid-to-polygonal cells with high nuclear grade, extensively infiltrating renal parenchyma
Characteristic features: Vesicular chromatin; prominent eosinophilic nucleoli; cytoplasmic hyaline, pink inclusionsInclusions sometimes rare; best seen around necrosis
sub_points: Inclusions sometimes rare; best seen around necrosis

Histologic Features.text: Brisk mitotic activity and areas of necrosis frequent, as are vascular invasion and extrarenal extension
Variant histology present in some tumors, usually in association with typical areas, including sclerosing (most common), spindled, pseudopapillary, and cystic

Immunohistochemistry.text: Among pediatric renal tumors, loss of nuclear staining for SNF5 (INI1) very sensitive and highly specific for RTK
Nonspecific polyphenotypic patterns for other antibodies due to trapping of antibodies in hyaline inclusions

Electron Microscopy.text: Ultrastructurally, hyaline inclusions correspond to whorled intermediate filaments

Renal Medullary Carcinoma.text: Older age, sickle cell trait, and occasionally glandular histology; SNF5 (INI1) lost, but keratin strong (+)

Cellular Mesoblastic Nephroma, Plump Cel.text: Spindle cell pattern and less invasive tumor periphery

Clear Cell Sarcoma of Kidney.text: Lack prominent nucleoli; retained staining for SNF5 (INI1)

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Many renal tumors show pseudorhabdoid features, but nuclear immunoreactivity for SNF5 (INI1) is retained in all such tumors

Abbreviations.text: Hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell carcinoma (HLRCC) syndrome

General Considerations.text: In all forms of inherited renal neoplasms, tumors are usually diagnosed at earlier age and are more likely to be multifocal and bilateralAt present, only exception to multifocality and bilaterality appears to be HLRCC syndrome
sub_points: At present, only exception to multifocality and bilaterality appears to be HLRCC syndrome

General Considerations.text: Because of consistent defects within tumor groups, genetic profiles of inherited neoplasms are relatively easier to studyKnowledge thus gained may be applied in similar, more common sporadic tumorsThis has resulted in better understanding of genetic mechanisms involved in various sporadic tumor subtypesMost targeted therapies currently in use/under investigation have been direct consequence of this better understanding of tumor genetics
sub_points: Knowledge thus gained may be applied in similar, more common sporadic tumorsThis has resulted in better understanding of genetic mechanisms involved in various sporadic tumor subtypesMost targeted therapies currently in use/under investigation have been direct consequence of this better understanding of tumor genetics
This has resulted in better understanding of genetic mechanisms involved in various sporadic tumor subtypes
Most targeted therapies currently in use/under investigation have been direct consequence of this better understanding of tumor genetics

Kidneys are usually of normal size and weight, chiefly because most cysts and RCCs are small

HPV Vaccine.text: Gardasil (Merck) vaccine approved by FDA in 2009 for prevention of penile cancer
Recommended for men 9-26 years of age and men 27 years of age and older who have sex with men

General Features.text: In HPV-related group, warty carcinoma shows distinctive cobblestone surface, and basaloid carcinoma cut surface is characteristically tan, solid, homogeneous, and deeply invasive

Anatomic Features.text: Poorly differentiated HPV-related carcinomas are more likely to develop around glans, where urethral-meatal mucosae merge (central tumors)
Lower grade keratinizing HPV-unrelated carcinomas are more prevalent in foreskin (peripheral tumors)

Histologic Features.text: HPV is frequently found in tumors with predominant basaloid cells (72%) or clear koilocytotic cells (47%)
Eosinophilic maturing keratinized cells are more common in HPV-negative tumors (81%)

Definitions.text: Interface vacuolar/lichenoid dermatitis with thickened papillary dermis/lamina propria showing band-like hyalinization (sclerosis)

Pathogenesis.text: Unknown

Presentation.text: Early lesions appear as pink or purple macules that become papules

Well-established lesions appear as white-gray, irregular geographic, and atrophic areas
Erosion, ulceration may be present
Thick, hyperkeratotic foci may also be seen
Advanced cases may result in acquired phimosis or paraphimosis
Lesions usually affect inner aspect of foreskin, glans, and perimeatal region; urethra may be involved
Lesions tend to be broad and multifocal

Treatment.text: Medical
Circumcision (if only/predominantly affecting foreskin)

Prognosis.text: Chronic condition

Terminology.text: Thickening of mucosal squamous epithelium without atypia

Definitions.text: Thickening of mucosal squamous epithelium without cytologic atypia

Reactive condition rather than specific entity

Site.text: SH may affect any penile mucosal compartment

Presentation.text: Usually found in continuity or slightly distant from in situ or invasive squamous cell carcinoma (SCC)

Micaceous balanitis and penile horn are clinically florid forms of SH with prominent hyperkeratosis

Treatment.text: Benign epithelial change and usually no treatment is required

Prognosis.text: May be precursor lesion of non-HPV-related variants of SCC, but more studies are required to confirm this hypothesis

Terminology.text: Sexually or congenitally transmitted infectious disease with mucocutaneous (and less commonly systemic) involvement
Stages include primary (direct inoculation), secondary (direct infiltration of skin by pathogens), latent (no symptoms), and tertiary (exuberant systemic immune response to a low burden of pathogens)

Clinical Issues.text: Primary: Ulceration ~ 3 weeks after inoculation that self resolves
Secondary: Protean appearance including condyloma lata, maculopapular rashes that begin on palms and soles, roseola-like rashes, and constitutional symptoms

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Chlamydia are an ancient group of obligate intracellular organisms with tiny genomes
All species share a biphasic lifestyle with 2 different developmental forms (elementary and reticulate bodies)
Clinically relevant species ofChlamydiaincludeC. trachomatis,C. pneumoniae, andC. psittaci
C. psittaciwas developed as an agent of biological warfare by both United States and former Soviet Union in early 20th century

Clinical Issues.text: Clinical manifestations include trachoma, genital infection in men and women (upper and lower), lymphogranuloma venereum, atypical pneumonia, and psittacosis
Nucleic acid amplification tests (NAATs) are preferred method for detectingChlamydiain clinical specimens
Trachoma: Most common among young children in developing countries
Genital infection: Most common in young, sexually active men and women (most common bacterial sexually transmitted disease)
LGV is most common in developing countries
C. pneumoniaehas been demonstrated by serology to have infected sizable percentages of adult populations in several countries (e.g., 9% of 6 week to 19 year olds in USA)

Chlamydophila: Genus that includesChlamydophila pneumoniaeandChlamydophila psittaci
Chlamydia: Genus that includesChlamydia trachomatis

Environmental Exposure.text: C. trachomatisexclusively infects humans, whileC. pneumoniaealso infects horses, marsupials, and frogs
C. psittacialso infects birds and numerous mammalian species

Infectious Agents.text: Chlamydiaceae (which includesChlamydophilaandChlamydia) is an ancient group of obligate intracellular organisms with tiny genomes

In 1999, molecular analysis ofChlamydiareassignedChlamydiaspecies into 2 groupsChlamydophila,which includesC. pneumoniaeandC. psittaci (both human pathogens) as well asChlamydophila pecorum,Chlamydophila felis,Chlamydophila abortus, andChlamydophila caviaeChlamydia, which includesC. trachomatis(human pathogen) as well asChlamydia suis,  andChlamydia muridarumRecent data suggests these organisms should be reunited under 1 species name, and the controversy has not been settled
sub_points: Chlamydophila,which includesC. pneumoniaeandC. psittaci (both human pathogens) as well asChlamydophila pecorum,Chlamydophila felis,Chlamydophila abortus, andChlamydophila caviae
Chlamydia, which includesC. trachomatis(human pathogen) as well asChlamydia suis,  andChlamydia muridarum
Recent data suggests these organisms should be reunited under 1 species name, and the controversy has not been settled

Infectious Agents.text: All species share a biphasic lifestyle with 2 different developmental formsElementary bodies (EB) are metabolically slowed-down, spore-like forms that are specialized for environmental survival and host cell attachmentEBs generally attach to nonphagocytic cells via a number of different receptors (CFTR, mannose receptor, etc.)Upon uptake (clathrin-mediated endocytosis) by an epithelial cell, EBs differentiate into reticulate bodies (RB) within host cell vacuolesRBs are the germinal forms, which actively divide 8-10x before differentiating back into EBsEBs can exit cell by slow extrusion or cell lysis and reinfect new cells
sub_points: Elementary bodies (EB) are metabolically slowed-down, spore-like forms that are specialized for environmental survival and host cell attachment
EBs generally attach to nonphagocytic cells via a number of different receptors (CFTR, mannose receptor, etc.)
Upon uptake (clathrin-mediated endocytosis) by an epithelial cell, EBs differentiate into reticulate bodies (RB) within host cell vacuoles
RBs are the germinal forms, which actively divide 8-10x before differentiating back into EBs
EBs can exit cell by slow extrusion or cell lysis and reinfect new cells

Infectious Agents.text: Virulence determinants include numerous mechanisms to utilize host cell nutrients and building blocks for cellular machinery
Differences between chlamydial species are mostly rooted in difference in "plasticity zone" of genome
Clinically relevant species ofChlamydiaincludeC. trachomatis,C. pneumoniae, andC. psittaci

C. trachomatisDivided into 15 serovars (based on OmpA [MOMP] antigenicity)Group 1 causes trachoma, genital tract disease, and conjunctivitis (trachoma biovar)Group 2 causes lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) and proctocolitis (LGV biovar)Plasticity zone encodes a perforin and phospholipase D proteinsStrains of trachoma biovar bind to squamocolumnar cells or conjunctiva, urethra, and rectum in women and men, endocervix and upper genital tract in women, and respiratory tract in infantsContact with host cells induces IL-8 and a neutrophilic responseStrains of LGV biovar are able to invade beyond mucosal epithelium and enter lymphatics where they multiply inside monocytes and macrophagesSpread is by sexual contact, childbirth, or hand-to-eye contact (trachoma)

Group 1 causes trachoma, genital tract disease, and conjunctivitis (trachoma biovar)
Group 2 causes lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) and proctocolitis (LGV biovar)

Strains of trachoma biovar bind to squamocolumnar cells or conjunctiva, urethra, and rectum in women and men, endocervix and upper genital tract in women, and respiratory tract in infants

Infectious Agents.text: C. psittaciPathogenesis is less well characterized, but genomic analysis of plasticity zone indicates that a toxin gene may be partially responsible for the more virulent strainsDeveloped as an agent of biological warfare by both United States and former Soviet Union in early 20th centurySpread is by contact with birds (even casual) or other domestic animals
sub_points: Pathogenesis is less well characterized, but genomic analysis of plasticity zone indicates that a toxin gene may be partially responsible for the more virulent strains

Epidemiology.text: Trachoma: Most common among young children in developing countries
Genital infection: Most common in young, sexually active men and women (most common bacterial sexually transmitted disease)LGV is most common in developing countries
sub_points: LGV is most common in developing countries

Epidemiology.text: C. pneumoniaehas been demonstrated by serology to have infected sizable percentages of adult populations in several countries (e.g., 9% of 6 week to 19 year olds in USA)

Laboratory Tests.text: Nucleic acid amplification tests (NAATs) are preferred method for detectingChlamydiain clinical specimens
16S PCR may also be used
As an intracellular pathogen,Chlamydiahas to be cultured in cells, which is rarely done for diagnostic purposes
Serologies may be used to diagnose some types of chlamydial disease (e.g.,C. pneumoniae)

Drugs.text: Macrolides, tetracycline, and quinolones are mainstays of treatment

Prognosis.text: Mortality is generally low (up to 1% withC. psittaciinfection), though several manifestations have significant long-term morbidity

Morphologic and Biochemical Characterist.text: Chlamydiaare pleomorphic organisms with the basic components of a gram-negative envelope, though they do not express peptidoglycan

Culture.text: Chlamydiaare obligate intracellular pathogens and must be cultured within eukaryotic cells, which is not routinely done in most clinical laboratories

Microbiologic Identification.text: Gold standard for identification is by NAAT

Trachoma.text: Initial infection may present with "pink eye" or mild irritation
Lymphoid hyperplasia may produce large white nodules on mucosa surface of eyelid in early stages
Advanced stages (repeated infection) leads to scarring with eyelash inversion and corneal ulceration (blindness)

Histologic Features.text: General: Organisms may be observable in intracellular vacuolesSilver staining and IHC are optimal means to visualizationCan also do 16S PCR
sub_points: Silver staining and IHC are optimal means to visualization
Can also do 16S PCR

Histologic Features.text: Psittacosis: Histopathologic features are not well described; may include myocarditis
Pneumonia: Standard features of atypical bacterial pneumonia

Trachoma.text: Viral conjunctivitis (negative culture, concurrent upper respiratory infection)
Advanced stages of trachoma: Squamous cell carcinoma of the conjunctiva

Lymphogranuloma Venereum.text: Differentiate from chancroid (has larger, more painful ulcers), particularly with other laboratory evidence to identify causative pathogen

Clinically Relevant Pathologic Features.text: Sexually transmitted organisms should have appropriate clinical history or exposure

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Intracytoplasmic inclusions are helpful but PCR &/or serology should be used to confirm diagnosis

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Caused by molluscum contagiosum viruses (poxvirus), transmitted by skin-to-skin contact

Clinical Issues.text: Primarily affects young children; in adults, considered STI; also affects immunosuppressed individuals
Dome-shaped papules with central umbilication; may number from a few to hundreds
Treatment: Watchful waiting (spontaneous resolution is the rule in healthy children); chemical, destructive, and immunologic methods

Microscopic Features.text: Hyperplastic epidermis with crater filled with distinct molluscum bodies (large, eosinophilic to basophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions that push aside nucleus)

Definitions.text: Infectious papules caused by poxvirus

Infectious Agents.text: Caused by molluscum contagiosum virus (poxvirus), transmitted by skin-to-skin contact

Age.text: Primarily affects young children, especially those with compromised epidermal barrier (i.e., atopic dermatitis)
In adults, molluscum is considered sexually transmitted and may coexist with other STIs
Immunosuppressed individuals, especially those with HIV, are at increased risk

Presentation.text: Skin-colored or pearly papules, with central umbilication, ranging 3-5 mm in diameter; may number from a few to hundreds"Giant" lesions up to 1.5 cm may be seen in those with AIDS
sub_points: "Giant" lesions up to 1.5 cm may be seen in those with AIDS

Presentation.text: Tend to occur on face, trunk, and extremities of childrenIn adults, favors "swimming trunk" distribution
sub_points: In adults, favors "swimming trunk" distribution

Presentation.text: Surrounding eczematous reaction heralds spontaneous resolution
Central umbilication is accentuated by applying liquid nitrogen to lesionAs lesion becomes frosted, central pit is more easily visualized
sub_points: As lesion becomes frosted, central pit is more easily visualized

Presentation.text: Molluscum folliculitis (MF)Presents similarly to ordinary folliculitisCan be inflammatory (more refractile to conventional treatment) or noninflammatoryMore commonly seen in immunocompromised patients
sub_points: Presents similarly to ordinary folliculitis
Can be inflammatory (more refractile to conventional treatment) or noninflammatory
More commonly seen in immunocompromised patients

Prognosis.text: As a rule, spontaneously resolves over months to years in immunocompetent children

Histologic Features.text: Hyperplastic epidermis with crater filled with distinct molluscum bodies (Henderson-Patterson bodies)
If ruptured, can elicit dense mixed inflammatory response
Lesions may occasionally be associated with other entitiesNevi, lupus, cryptococcosis, HPV, and others
sub_points: Nevi, lupus, cryptococcosis, HPV, and others

Histologic Features.text: Molluscum folliculitisCharacteristic molluscum bodies seen within follicular epithelium ± surrounding inflammation
sub_points: Characteristic molluscum bodies seen within follicular epithelium ± surrounding inflammation

Cytologic Features.text: Large eosinophilic to basophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions that push aside nucleus (Henderson-Patterson bodies) are pathognomonic

Histological.text: Diagnosis is obvious once molluscum bodies are identified
Rarely, if ruptured with dense inflammation, may be confused with ruptured cyst

Clinical.text: Easy to diagnose because of the smooth dome shape and distinctive central umbilication
Common wartsVerrucous and sometimes filiform; no central umbilication
sub_points: Verrucous and sometimes filiform; no central umbilication

Clinical.text: Condyloma acuminataOften papillomatous, of varying sizes; no central umbilication
sub_points: Often papillomatous, of varying sizes; no central umbilication

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Large, eosinophilic to basophilic molluscum bodies are characteristic and hard to miss on histology

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Haemophilus ducreyi(gram-negative coccobacillus) is causative organism

Clinical Issues.text: Papule develops, which becomes a painful ulcer
~ 25-50% develop lymphadenopathy, which may evolve into buboes

Microscopic Features.text: "Trilayer" from top to bottom (ulcer, granulation tissue, and lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate)
Organisms rare in tissue and best visualized as coccobacillus-shaped organisms on Gram stains of smears ("school of fish")

Definitions.text: Sexually transmitted bacterial infection

Infectious Agents.text: Haemophilus ducreyi(gram-negative streptobacillary facultative anaerobe)
Women likely serve as reservoir (less often symptomatic than men)

Incidence.text: Leading cause of genital ulcerations in developing countries in past, but currently declining
Extremely rare in United States

Site.text: Fourchette, labia minora much more common than urethra, vagina

Presentation.text: Papule(s) at 4-7 days after inoculation
Tender to painful nonindurative ulcer(s) following with irregular serpiginous border, undermined edges, and friable base
Satellite lesions may develop
~ 25-50% develop lymphadenopathy/painful lymphadenitis, which may evolve to buboes (abscess)

Drugs.text: Azithromycin, ceftriaxone, ciprofloxacin, or erythromycin

Prognosis.text: Good response to treatment

Histologic Features.text: Usually, 3 zones appreciated histologicallyUlcer with acute necroinflammatory infiltrate (neutrophils, erythrocytes, and fibrin), usually narrowZone of granulation tissue beneath ulcer bed with associated thrombosed vessels and degenerative changes in their wallsDense infiltrate of lymphocytes and plasma cells at base
sub_points: Ulcer with acute necroinflammatory infiltrate (neutrophils, erythrocytes, and fibrin), usually narrow
Zone of granulation tissue beneath ulcer bed with associated thrombosed vessels and degenerative changes in their walls
Dense infiltrate of lymphocytes and plasma cells at base

Histologic Features.text: Adjacent epidermis may be acanthotic
Organisms, if identified, tend to be in superficial portion of lesion

Cytologic Features.text: Short fascicles of gram-negative 1.5 micrometer coccobacilli-shaped organisms in parallel chains (“school of fish”)

Electron Microscopy.text: Aggregates of coccobacilli (seen as rods 1.3 μm long and 0.3 μm broad with rounded ends) in interstitial space and rarely in phagosomes or macrophages

Cultures.text: Organisms grows on chocolate agar or rabbit blood with vancomycin

Syphilis.text: Spirochetes on silver stains and immunohistochemistry

Granuloma Inguinale.text: Large histiocytes engulfing bipolar organisms resembling safety pins

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Culture or possibly smear findings are more reliable than biopsies
Ulcer itself is a risk factor for contracting human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) due to compromised skin barrier and increased recruited CD4 T cells

Terminology.text: Deep fibromatosis: Desmoid tumor
Palmar fibromatosis: Dupuytren contracture
Plantar fibromatosis: Ledderhose disease
Penile fibromatosis: Peyronie disease
Myofibroblastic proliferations with infiltrative growth pattern that show local recurrences but not metastasis

Clinical Issues.text: Palmar fibromatosis4-6% of Caucasian adults > 50 years of age
sub_points: 4-6% of Caucasian adults > 50 years of age

Clinical Issues.text: Deep fibromatosis2.4-4.43 new cases per 100,000 persons per year
sub_points: 2.4-4.43 new cases per 100,000 persons per year

Clinical Issues.text: Recurrences common for both superficial and deep fibromatoses, but deaths only from deep fibromatoses
Increased incidence in familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP)

Microscopic Features.text: Sweeping fascicles of myofibroblasts
Smooth nuclear membranes and small nucleoli in most cells
Occasional cells with stellate cytoplasmic contours
Occasional foci with storiform pattern similar to nodular fasciitis
Some cases show keloid-like collagen
Small but conspicuous vessels
Gaping, thin-walled vessels with perivascular sclerosis often feature of mesenteric fibromatosis

Ancillary Tests.text: β-catenin positive (nuclear), especially in deep lesions, SMA(+); desmin(-), keratins(-), CD117(+/-)

Synonyms.text: Deep fibromatosis: Aggressive fibromatosis, desmoid tumor
Superficial fibromatoses: Palmar fibromatosis (Dupuytren contracture, Dupuytren disease), plantar fibromatosis (Ledderhose disease), penile fibromatosis (Peyronie disease), knuckle pads

Definitions.text: Palmar fibromatosis: Nodular myofibroblastic proliferation of volar surface of hand that is prone to local persistence, but does not metastasize
Plantar fibromatosis: Nodular myofibroblastic proliferation of plantar surface of foot that is prone to local persistence, but does not metastasize
Peyronie disease: Penile fibrous lesion causing various deformities; initially pain with erection, erectile dysfunction
Knuckle pads: Well-circumscribed thickening of skin over metacarpophalangeal and, more commonly, proximal interphalangeal joints
Deep fibromatosis: Myofibroblastic proliferation of deep soft tissues with infiltrative growth pattern; prone to local recurrences, but does not metastasize

sub_points: 4-6% of Caucasian adults > 50 years of age; reports of up to 75% of Celtic males

Incidence.text: Plantar fibromatosis1-2 per 100,000 persons per year (northern Europe)Most patients 30-50 years of age; slight male predominance
sub_points: 1-2 per 100,000 persons per year (northern Europe)

Incidence.text: Penile fibromatosisAbout 3.5% of white men > 50 years of age

Incidence.text: Deep fibromatosis2.4-4.43 new cases per 100,000 persons per year (Scandinavian data)

Deep fibromatoses present as firm large massesRelationship to age and genderIn children and older adults, no gender predominance: Lesions of shoulders, chest wall, back, thigh, head, and neckIn women in childbearing years: Abdominal wall

Presentation.text: Familial adenomatous polyposis-associated (FAP) lesionsRisk of fibromatoses is 2.56/1,000 person-years;  comparative risk is 852x that of general population
sub_points: Risk of fibromatoses is 2.56/1,000 person-years;  comparative risk is 852x that of general population

Presentation.text: Occasionally associated with scar ("cicatricial fibromatosis")

Treatment.text: Superficial fibromatoses treated by excision
Nonsurgical treatments for penile lesions: Verapamil, colchicine, Potaba, L-carnitine, and liposomal superoxide dismutase
Deep fibromatoses treated by wide excision; for unresectable lesions, radiation, chemotherapy, hormone therapy

Prognosis.text: Recurrences common for both superficial and deep fibromatoses; occasional deaths from deep fibromatoses

Histologic Features.text: Sweeping fascicles of myofibroblastsSmooth nuclear membranes, delicate nucleoli in most cells, occasional cells with stellate cytoplasmic contours
sub_points: Smooth nuclear membranes, delicate nucleoli in most cells, occasional cells with stellate cytoplasmic contours

Histologic Features.text: Uniformly distributed collagen, some cases with keloid-like collagen
Prominent vascular patternSmall but conspicuous vessels

Histologic Features.text: Minimal background inflammation
Scattered giant cells (plantar fibromatoses)

Immunohistochemistry.text: β-catenin(+) (nuclear), especially in deep lesions, SMA(+), desmin(-), keratins(-), CD117 can be (+/-) (pitfall in mesenteric lesions)

Clear Cell Sarcoma.text: Most involve hands and feet of young adults
Packeted arrangement of spindle cells, scattered giant cells; S100 protein, HMB-45, Melan-A positive,EWS-ATF1gene fusion

Epithelioid Sarcoma.text: Epithelioid cells arranged around necrotic zones, reminiscent of granulomatous inflammation; cytokeratin, EMA, CD34 positive, loss of nuclear INI1

Tenosynovial Giant Cell Tumor (Giant Cel.text: Usually involves fingers and toes of middle-aged women
Rounded cells, giant cells, foamy macrophages, hemosiderin, CD68(+), clusterin(+)

Scar.text: Disorganized myofibroblastic proliferation without nodular configuration; β-catenin negative

Leiomyoma and Leiomyosarcoma.text: Perpendicularly oriented fascicles of spindle cells with brightly eosinophilic cytoplasm, blunt-ended nuclei, paranuclear vacuoles, none to few mitoses (leiomyoma), bland cytologic features (leiomyoma) or scattered mitoses (leiomyosarcoma), and atypical nuclei (leiomyosarcoma)
Actin, desmin, calponin, H-caldesmon positive; S100 protein, CD34, β-catenin negative

Low-Grade Fibromyxoid Sarcoma.text: Disorganized and swirled arrangement of fibroblastic cells with hyperchromatic nuclei, variable myxoid background, cellularity similar to that of fibromatosis
S100 protein, desmin, CD34, β-catenin negative; occasionally actin(+), claudin-1(+), epithelial membrane antigen(+);  pitfall with perineurioma,FUS-CREB3L2fusion

Terminology.text: Life-threatening deep, acute, aggressive bacterial (or rarely fungal) infection of deep soft tissue, including fascia

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Group A β-hemolytic streptococcal infection (Streptococcus pyogenes) is most common; more cases now polymicrobial

Clinical Issues.text: Clues to clinical diagnosis includePain out of proportion to physical exam, hemorrhagic bullae, and vital sign abnormalities
sub_points: Pain out of proportion to physical exam, hemorrhagic bullae, and vital sign abnormalities

Microscopic Features.text: Necrosis is invariably present; usually involves epidermis, dermis, and upper portion of subcutis
Mixed inflammatory infiltrate usually seen in viable areas bordering areas of necrosis

Definitions.text: Life-threatening deep, acute, aggressive bacterial (or fungal) infection of deep soft tissue and fascia

Environmental Exposure.text: Predisposing factors identified for NF includeIntravenous drug use, diabetes, malignancy, alcohol abuse, chronic kidney and liver diseasesHypersensitivity, burns, vascular issues, trauma, needle sticks, and medical drugs
sub_points: Intravenous drug use, diabetes, malignancy, alcohol abuse, chronic kidney and liver diseases
Hypersensitivity, burns, vascular issues, trauma, needle sticks, and medical drugs

Infectious Agents.text: Group A β-hemolytic strep(Streptococcus pyogenes) most common, but often polymicrobial
Community-acquired methicillin-resistantStaphylococcus aureus(CA-MRSA) also causative
Other causative agents includeVibrio vulnificus,Aeromonas hydrophila, and Enterobacteriaceae (Escherichia coli,Pseudomonasspp., andKlebsiellaspp.)
sub_points: Vibrio vulnificus,Aeromonas hydrophila, and Enterobacteriaceae (Escherichia coli,Pseudomonasspp., andKlebsiellaspp.)

Incidence.text: 0.40 cases per 100,000 people per year
Estimated 500-1,000 cases per year in USA

Site.text: Abdomen, perineum, and extremities most common

Presentation.text: Often nonspecific signs in early stages can mimic cellulitis or erysipelasTenderness, swelling, erythema, pain
sub_points: Tenderness, swelling, erythema, pain

Presentation.text: Clues to clinical diagnosis includePain out of proportion to physical exam, hemorrhagic bullae, crepitus, and vital sign abnormalities
sub_points: Pain out of proportion to physical exam, hemorrhagic bullae, crepitus, and vital sign abnormalities

Presentation.text: Erythematous areas can rapidly become swollen and cyanotic, then gangrenous in 5 days or less
Fever, malaise, and altered sensorium may be presentDiabetes is a common predisposing factor
sub_points: Diabetes is a common predisposing factor

Laboratory Tests.text: Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) very elevated

Treatment.text: Broad spectrum IV antibiotics given emergently
Change to specific antibiotics when culture and sensitivities evaluated
Emergency aggressive surgical debridement or amputation can be curativeOften necessary to repeat
sub_points: Often necessary to repeat

Prognosis.text: 25-50% mortality, which improves if therapy given emergently
VibrioorAeromonasassociated with higher mortality

General Features.text: MR, CT scan, ultrasound, or plain films can be of helpDetection of air within tissue radiologically is highly suggestive of NF, but false negatives can occur
sub_points: Detection of air within tissue radiologically is highly suggestive of NF, but false negatives can occur

Histologic Features.text: Often subepidermal edema
Necrosis is invariably present and usually involves epidermis, dermis, and upper portion of subcutis
Intense mixed inflammatory infiltrate usually admixed with numerous bacteria in dermis, subcutaneous tissue, and in viable areas bordering areas of necrosis
Septic vasculitis with perivascular inflammation, fibrinoid necrosis, and sometimes thrombi in vessels
Gram or GMS stains can be used to help identify organisms

Frozen Sections.text: Biopsy must be down to fascial level
Very rapid way to diagnose NF

Finger Test.text: 2 cm vertical incision is made into adjacent normal-appearing skin

Finger or hemostat is placed in a 2 cm vertical incision in normal skin down to junction of subcutaneous tissue and deep fasciaIf subcutaneous tissue is easily dissected off fascia, or "dishwater pus" is expelled, test is positiveCharacteristic "dishwater pus" or lack of bleeding also indicate a positive testPathognomonic for NF if positive
sub_points: If subcutaneous tissue is easily dissected off fascia, or "dishwater pus" is expelled, test is positive
Characteristic "dishwater pus" or lack of bleeding also indicate a positive test
Pathognomonic for NF if positive

Culture.text: Can help identify causative organisms and help guide antimicrobial therapy

Rapid streptococcal screen may be helpful to identify β-hemolyticStreptococcus(most common organism)If positive, provides rapid identification of most common causative agent (β-hemolyticStreptococcus)
sub_points: If positive, provides rapid identification of most common causative agent (β-hemolyticStreptococcus)

Gram or Other Special Stains.text: Can be used to help identify organisms but is not as sensitive or specific as culture

GMS or PAS.text: Either may be helpful when searching for a fungal cause of necrotizing fasciitis

Tissue Oxygen Saturation by Near-Infrare.text: High specificity and sensitivity for differentiating NF from more benign entities

Cellulitis or Erysipelas.text: Early NF and cellulitis often indistinguishable
Clinically NF is more painful, gangrenous earlier, and often crepitant

Pyoderma Gangrenosum (PG).text: Classic clinical lesion has rolled or undermined edges
Epidermal necrosis and deep ulcer is focal

Sweet Syndrome (SS).text: Clinically presents with painful plaques and fever
Dermal neutrophilic infiltrate is typically sheet-like

Terminology.text: Primary infection: Initial manifestation of viral infection in individuals without preexisting antibodies
Latency: Time period after initial infection before and between reactivation periods
Recurrent infection: Reactivation of HSV after latency

Clinical Issues.text: HSV2 responsible for 70-90% of genital herpes, though HSV1 increasing in incidence

Symptoms 3-7 days after inoculation1st: Painful burning and stinging with some constitutional symptoms2nd: Vesicles 12-48 hours later, lasting 10-12 days3rd: Disrupted vesicles form ulcers lasting 1-2 weeks
sub_points: 1st: Painful burning and stinging with some constitutional symptoms
2nd: Vesicles 12-48 hours later, lasting 10-12 days
3rd: Disrupted vesicles form ulcers lasting 1-2 weeks

Clinical Issues.text: Slightly more common in females
Increased in African Americans and Hispanics

Microscopic Features.text: Ulcerated epidermis or intraepidermal blister
Intracellular ballooning and reticular degeneration of keratinocytes
Acantholytic keratinocytes with multinucleation, nuclear molding, and chromatin margination ("ground-glass"), most common cytopathic effect
Cowdry A cytopathic effect with large eosinophilic nuclear inclusions and clear halo, less common

sub_points: Initial manifestation in individuals without preexisting antibodies

Definitions.text: LatencyTime period after initial infection before and between reactivation periods
sub_points: Time period after initial infection before and between reactivation periods

Definitions.text: Recurrent infectionReactivation of HSV after latency
sub_points: Reactivation of HSV after latency

Infectious Agents.text: HSV1 and HSV2: Double-stranded enveloped DNA viruses
Transmission via viral shedding ± symptoms
After initial infection, virus transported to (sacral) sensory and autonomic ganglia (latent reservoir)

Epidemiology.text: 28% HSV2 seropositivity prevalence if pregnant

Incidence.text: 700,000 new cases per year in USA
HSV2 responsible for 70-90% of genital herpes, though HSV1 increasing in incidence
Increased risk with number of sexual partners, poverty, lower education, homosexuality

Ethnicity.text: Increased in African Americans and Hispanics

Presentation.text: Symptoms 3-7 days after inoculation1st: Painful burning and stinging ± constitutional symptoms2nd: Vesicles 12-48 hours later, lasting 10-12 days3rd: Disrupted vesicles form ulcers (in immunocompromised patients) or erosions lasting 1-2 weeks
sub_points: 1st: Painful burning and stinging ± constitutional symptoms
2nd: Vesicles 12-48 hours later, lasting 10-12 days
3rd: Disrupted vesicles form ulcers (in immunocompromised patients) or erosions lasting 1-2 weeks

Presentation.text: Ulcerative and nodular lesions (when chronic) may simulate carcinoma in immunosuppressed patients
Lymphadenopathy may be present

Natural History.text: Reactivation with stress, menses, extensive ultraviolet light exposure, or immunosuppression
Primary infection during pregnancy may lead to abortion, premature delivery, or neonatal herpes
Highest risk of neonatal herpes with vaginal delivery, prolonged ruptured membranes before cesarean section, or if cervical involvement

Drugs.text: Acyclovir and other antivirals (valacyclovir, famciclovir)

Prognosis.text: ~ 80% recurrence rate
Up to 4 recurrences/year common as virus harbors indefinitely in ganglia (HSV2 > HSV1 reactivation)

General Features.text: Small (1-3 mm) grouped vesicles may be present on mucosa, possibly extending to skin
More commonly, vesicles rupture leaving erosions or ulcers (immunocompromised patients)

Histologic Features.text: Ulcerated epidermis or intraepidermal blister
Intracellular ballooning and reticular degeneration of keratinocytes
Usually prominent acute (or less commonly, chronic) inflammatory infiltrate
Follicular involvement associated with marked inflammation and secondary necrosis
Marked pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia can occur, especially in immunocompromised patients

Cytologic Features.text: Acantholytic keratinocytes with multinucleation, nuclear molding, and chromatin margination ("ground-glass"), most common cytopathic effect
Cowdry A cytopathic effect with large eosinophilic nuclear inclusions and clear halo, less common

Cytology.text: Variable sensitivity ranging from 87% (if blisters) to 50% (if ulcers) (Tzanck prep, Diff-Quik, Wright, Papanicolaou, or ThinPrep)

Immunohistochemistry.text: HSV1 and HSV2 antibodiesHighlights infected cells without classic viral cytopathic changes
sub_points: Highlights infected cells without classic viral cytopathic changes

PCR.text: Can be performed on fresh or formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded tissue

Squamous Cell Carcinoma.text: May be associated with vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia
Infiltrative, irregular nests of atypical squamous epithelial cells with desmoplastic stromal reaction

Lymphoma.text: Dense, monotonous infiltrate of atypical lymphocytes

Reparative Changes Adjacent to Ulcer.text: No chromatin margination, nuclear molding, or viral inclusions in squamous cells

Syphilis, Granuloma Inguinale, and Chanc.text: Absence of characteristic viral cytopathic effect

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Discrete vulvar ulcer or extensive inflammation, especially around adnexal structures, should always raise possibility of herpesvirus infection

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Most often related to HPV 16

Clinical Issues.text: Often multifocal
Benign-looking papules
Usually affecting skin of shaft of young adults
May also affect glans and coronal sulcus

Microscopic Features.text: Proliferation of atypical basaloid and koilocytic cells as scattered single units or involving full thickness of epithelium

Definitions.text: Multifocal HPV-related papular condition affecting anogenital region in young adults
Lesions exhibit spectrum of changes from dysplasia to in situ carcinoma; usually associated with favorable prognosis

Etiology.text: Related to high-risk types of HPV, especially type 16
Other types of HPV  (18, 31, 32, 33, 34, 35, 39, 42, 48, 51, 52, 53, and 54) have also been implicated

Pathogenesis.text: Oncogenic HPV elaborate proteins that interfere with normal cellular homeostasis

Incidence.text: Unknown and probably underestimated
Immunosuppression, including HIV infection, greatly increases risk for bowenoid papulosis

Presentation.text: Young, sexually active adults with solitary or more often multiple soft papules or macules with flat surfaceSurface may be verruciform
sub_points: Surface may be verruciform

Presentation.text: Lesions are often small, red, brown, or flesh-coloredUsually affect skin of shaftMay also affect epithelium of glans, coronal sulcus, or foreskinMay be pruritic or painful
sub_points: Usually affect skin of shaft

Presentation.text: Usually asymptomatic
Lesions in immunosuppressed patients tend to be more widespread

Treatment.text: Usually may be treated with locally destructive modalitiesImportant to remember that BP may be multifocal and has malignant potential: Follow-up is advised
sub_points: Important to remember that BP may be multifocal and has malignant potential: Follow-up is advised

Prognosis.text: Most BP lesions run benign course with spontaneous regression occurring within several months
Some lesions (especially in older or immunocompromised patients) last longer or never regress at all
Minority of lesions evolve to invasive squamous cell carcinoma (SCC)

Histologic Features.text: Proliferation of atypical cells with high nuclear/cytoplasmic ratio (basaloid cells) that may be scattered throughout epidermis, often with preserved maturation
Koilocytic-like changes are also seen in most cases
Range of atypia from scattered atypical cells to low-grade dysplasia to full thickness atypia of the squamous epithelium
Most lesions are indistinguishable from squamous cell carcinoma in situ (SCCIS)
Morphological features are similar to HPV-related penile intraepithelial neoplasia (PeIN)
Variable increased pigmentation of basal layer

Squamous Cell Carcinoma In Situ (SCCIS).text: Despite clinically benign-looking appearance of BP, histopathologic findings reveal features that may be identical to those of SCCIS
Clinical correlation is crucial to make the distinction

Treated Flat Condyloma.text: Prominent degenerative changes that tend to be focal
Pallor of epithelium, nuclear enlargement, necrotic keratinocytes
Increase in number of mitotic figures (metaphase arrest)
Atypical mitoses should not be seen
Clinical correlation is necessary to make correct diagnosis

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: BP is clinicopathological diagnosis
Histologically, most cases are indistinguishable from SCCIS
Histopathological features similar to warty/basaloid PeIN
Presence of only scattered atypical cells or more patchy pattern of full thickness squamous dysplasia may suggest BP
Clinical correlation is crucial to make distinction

Histologic Features.text: SCC with mixed sarcomatoid featuresAt least focal areas of usual SCC are observed in > 1/2 of sarcomatoid carcinomasIn some cases, typical areas of verrucous, papillary, and basaloid SCC may be presentRegardless of presence of other histologic subtypes, all of these tumors are considered sarcomatoid carcinoma

In some cases, typical areas of verrucous, papillary, and basaloid SCC may be present
Regardless of presence of other histologic subtypes, all of these tumors are considered sarcomatoid carcinoma

Histologic Features.text: Other mixed patternsMixed usual-warty SCCs are unusual mixed penile carcinomasMixtures of basaloid SCC with usual SCC are also unusualPapillary SCC admixed with usual SCC may be seen in minority of casesOther mixtures include adenobasaloid SCC, mucoepidermoid SCC, and polymorphic variantsComplex verruciform tumors: Composed of variable proportions of benign condyloma, warty, verrucous, and papillary SCCs

Anatomical Extension.text: Many tumors invade penile erectile tissues
Tumors limited to lamina propria are rare

Pure Squamous Cell Carcinoma Variants.text: Tumors should be adequately sampled in order to identify minor mixed areas, which may be of higher grade
Strict criteria should be applied in histologic subtyping
High-grade areas and variants may have random distribution
Sampling is key in all verrucous carcinomas to identify areas of hybrid SCC pattern
Mixed SCC with basaloid component behaves better clinically than pure basaloid SCC

Sarcomatoid Carcinoma.text: In sarcomatoid carcinoma, presence of other intermingled SCC variants is not unusual
Sarcomatoid carcinoma is clinically aggressive regardless of presence and extension of other morphologic components

Terminology.text: Extramammary Paget disease (EMPD)

Clinical Issues.text: Erythematous patches or plaques with sharply defined bordersPruritus is frequent
sub_points: Pruritus is frequent

Clinical Issues.text: May clinically mimic chronic eczema

Microscopic.text: Round, large, pale cells in all levels of epidermis arranged as single units or confluent aggregatesMay form true glandular luminaMay contain intracytoplasmic melanin
sub_points: May form true glandular lumina
May contain intracytoplasmic melanin

Microscopic.text: Round vesicular nuclei with prominent nucleoli
Abundant clear cytoplasm
Absence of intercellular bridges
Paget cells often extend to adnexal structures
Flattened basal keratinocytes

Primary EMPD positive for CK7 and negative for CK20

Definitions.text: Adenocarcinoma involving epidermis/squamous epithelium and commonly extending to epithelium of eccrine glands &/or hair follicles (adenocarcinoma in situ)
May involve dermis/ lamina propria in minority of cases

Pathogenesis.text: Uncertain
Cases limited to epidermis are postulated to originate from intraepidermal portion of sweat glands or from intraepidermal stem cells

Terminology.text: Cellular shrinkage with loss of cytoplasmic volume of prostatic ductal acinar unit and surrounding stroma

Clinical Issues.text: Frequency increases with age; more common after 6th decade of life
Remarkable in routine practice as morphologic mimicker of adenocarcinoma in prostate biopsy

Microscopic.text: Most commonly in peripheral zone
All patterns of atrophy are characterized by acinar cells with scant cytoplasm producing higher nuclear:cytoplasmic ratio
Glands contain crowded and hyperchromatic nuclei, imparting more basophilic appearance
Atrophy may be diffuse or widespread; linked to aging, androgen deprivation, and radiotherapy
Main morphologic types of focal atrophy include simple atrophy (SA), SA with cyst formation, postatrophic hyperplasia (PAH), and partial atrophy (PA)
SA consists of atrophic acini that are spaced relatively similarly to normal glands
SA with cyst formation shows cystic dilatation of atrophic acini
PAH consists of proliferative atrophic acini arranged in lobules, often surrounding central larger dilated duct
Unlike other forms of atrophy, PA contains relatively modest amount of pale or clear cytoplasm and has less crowded nuclei
Most are positive for basal cell markers; PA and PAH may have patchy or absent staining
Main differential diagnosis is prostate adenocarcinoma with atrophic features
PA is common reason for consultations of atypical glands concerning for cancer in biopsies

Definitions.text: Cellular shrinkage with loss of cytoplasmic volume of prostatic ductal acinar unit and surrounding stroma

Causes.text: Diffuse atrophy linked to aging, androgen deprivation, and radiotherapy
Secondary compression by BPH nodule, e.g., peripheral zone atrophy in BPH of transition zone
End result of severe chronic inflammation [postinflammatory atrophy (PIA)]
Chronic local ischemia has also been suggested

Epidemiology.text: Very common; seen in 85% of prostates in autopsies of men > 40 years of age
Frequency increases with age; more common after 6th decade of life

Site.text: Commonly involves peripheral zone and, less frequently, central and transition zones

Presentation.text: Asymptomatic; incidental histologic finding
Remarkable in routine practice as morphologic mimicker of adenocarcinoma in prostate biopsy

Treatment.text: None

Prognosis.text: Benign course; presence in negative biopsy lowers risk for subsequent prostate cancer
Conflicting evidence for PIA as precursor to cancer; some suggests association with nonlethal cancer

Histologic Features.text: Characterized by acinar cells with scant cytoplasm imparting higher nuclear:cytoplasmic ratio
Maintains overall lobular configuration with angular or slit-like (collapsed) glands, occasionally with parent duct
Glands contain crowded and hyperchromatic nuclei, imparting more basophilic appearance
Since secretory cells have minimal to no cytoplasm, they resemble basal cells and impart single-cell type appearance
Glands may very rarely contain intraluminal mucin and crystalloids
Surrounding stroma with variable amount of fibrosis
Chronic inflammation may be seen in association with atrophic acini

Diffuse Atrophy.text: Widespread, shows uniform involvement of all glands

Focal Atrophy.text: Localized or patchy atrophy of glands

Terminology.text: Nodular prostate enlargement due to cellular proliferation of prostatic glands and stroma associated with lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS)

Clinical Issues.text: Leading cause of morbidity in elderly men
Seen in 50% of men in their 50s, up to 80-90% of men in their 70s and 80s
Most common noncancerous cause of serum PSA elevation
TURP remains standard in management
Choice of therapy based on symptoms, prostate size, and existing comorbidities
Without associated LUTS, features of glandular and stromal proliferation in needle biopsies shouldnotbe labeled as BPH

Macroscopic.text: Hallmark of BPH is nodular prostatic enlargement
Hyperplastic nodules are mainly centered on proximal prostatic urethra involving transition zone and submucosal compartment

Microscopic.text: Epithelial predominant hyperplasia shows nodules composed of tightly clustered expanded ductal acinar elements
Stromal predominant hyperplasia composed of bland spindle cells with little cytoplasm and plump nuclei seen surrounding small blood vessels
Morphologic variants: Small glandular, cribriform, basal cell, leiomyomatous nodule, and phyllodes-type hyperplasia
Differential diagnosis for epithelial hyperplasia: Pseudohyperplastic variant of acinar carcinoma, atypical adenomatous hyperplasia
Differential diagnosis for stromal hyperplasia: Specialized stromal tumors of prostate, smooth muscle tumors, solitary fibrous tumors

Definitions.text: Nodular prostate enlargement due to cellular proliferation of prostatic glands and stroma associated with lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS)

Solitary Fibrous Tumor of Prostate.text: Uniform bland spindle cells with haphazard patternless pattern, dense ropey collagen, more variable cellularity, and staghorn vessels

Terminology.text: Benign proliferation of glands indigenously situated along verumontanum of posterior prostatic urethra

Definitions.text: Benign proliferation of glands indigenously situated along verumontanum of prostatic urethra; usually > 5 glands in focus is considered hyperplastic but can be florid
Verumontanum or seminal colliculus is located at posterior prostatic urethral wall where utricle and bilateral ejaculatory ducts merge with prostatic urethra

Origin.text: Morphologic evidence suggests origin from urethral mucosal glands, which occupy most distal portion of prostatic ducts, ejaculatory ducts, and utricle

Another possibility is origin from utricle, since this structure developmentally acquires morphologic and functional features of prostateHowever, presence of VMGH exclusively along prostatic urethra argues against this theory
sub_points: However, presence of VMGH exclusively along prostatic urethra argues against this theory

Incidence.text: Reported in 14-32% of prostatectomy specimens

sub_points: Unlikely to be seen in TURP specimens, since verumontanum is spared in this procedure

Treatment.text: None

Prognosis.text: Benign course, histologic variation

Glands are often back-to-back with minimal interglandular stroma

Origin.text: During embryogenesis, mesonephric or wolffian duct gives rise to rete testis, epididymis, vas deferens, and seminal vesicles

Presentation.text: Usually as rare, incidental histologic finding, in TUR for obstruction due to BPH

Treatment.text: None required

Prognosis.text: Benign lesion, notable predominantly as rare mimic of adenocarcinoma

Size.text: Measures 0.1-0.7 cm in TUR of prostate (TURP) specimens, usually not grossly apparent

Histologic Features.text: Composed of tubules or acini arranged in somewhat lobular clusters with distinctive, dense, colloid-like luminal material
Tubules are lined by single layer of bland cuboidal, flattened, or low columnar cells
Cytoplasm is typically scant, pink, appearing atrophic
Nuclei are round, regular, and typically with inconspicuous nucleoli, although occasionally, they may be prominent
Tubules may have infiltrative-appearing growth pattern or may show intraluminal papillary fronds
Hyperplasia may be florid; tubules may appear to infiltrate between bladder neck muscle bundles and into periprostatic connective tissues
Tubules may be seen intimately admixed with nerves and ganglia
May contain infiltrative-appearing cords of microacini that lack colloid-like material and, along with prominent nucleoli, may mimic prostate cancer
Infrequently may appear as nodules of ill-formed small glands intermixed with spindle cells, mimicking sclerosing adenosis or higher grade prostate cancer
Infrequently, prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN)-like architecture with intraluminal fronds may be present

Immunohistochemistry.text: Diffuse nuclear positivity for PAX8; PSA/PAP(-)
Most, but not all, are HMWCK (34βE12)(+)

Verumontanum Mucosal Gland Hyperplasia.text: Microacinar lesion along verumontanum and adjacent urethra at openings of utricle and ejaculatory ducts
Tubules are lined by single layer of cuboidal to columnar cells with underlying basal cell layer and abundant intraluminal corpora amylacea or concretions

Nephrogenic Adenoma.text: Also PAX8(+) lesion, but associated with reactive/reparative/inflammatory milieu
Mainly periurethral in location, focally/secondarily extending into prostate
Cystic tubules may contain colloid-like material in subset
Frequently shows hobnail cytology, at least focally
May have exophytic papillary growth overlying tubular parenchyma
May be PSA/PAP(+), may be AMACR(+)

Benign Small Acinar Lesions.text: Benign prostatic lesions in differential of atypical small acinar proliferations, including small glandular BPH, adenosis, atrophy, and sclerosing adenosis
PSA/PAP(+), PAX8(-), p63/HMWCK(+) basal cell layer, lack luminal colloid-like material

Acinar Adenocarcinoma.text: Malignant glands are more atypical (nucleomegaly, nucleoli) and infiltrative, lacking lobular pattern of mesonephric hyperplasia
PSA/PAP(+), PAX8(-), ERG[(+) in 30-50%], lack p63/HMWCK(+) basal cell layer

Terminology.text: High-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (HGPIN)Preneoplastic process of epithelium lining prostatic ducts and acini characterized by nuclear atypia resembling invasive adenocarcinoma
sub_points: Preneoplastic process of epithelium lining prostatic ducts and acini characterized by nuclear atypia resembling invasive adenocarcinoma

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Generally similar to that of prostatic adenocarcinomaTMPRSS::ERGfusion (and ERG expression by IHC) may be seen in minority of HGPIN
sub_points: TMPRSS::ERGfusion (and ERG expression by IHC) may be seen in minority of HGPIN

Clinical Issues.text: Present as isolated diagnosis in ~ 5% of needle biopsies
Present in nearly all prostates harboring adenocarcinoma vs. 43% of age-matched controls
Incidence ↑ with age, reaching up to 67% in 8th decade
Associated with ~ 25% risk of finding prostate carcinoma in subsequent biopsy
Usually no treatment needed for isolated HGPIN

Microscopic.text: Preexistent ducts and acini are lined by crowded epithelial cells with abnormal cytologic featuresEnlarged monomorphic nuclei, prominent nucleoli, hyperchromasia, nuclear overlap, amphophilic cytoplasm
sub_points: Enlarged monomorphic nuclei, prominent nucleoli, hyperchromasia, nuclear overlap, amphophilic cytoplasm

Microscopic.text: Preserved or discontinuous basal cell layer may be readily identified on H&E or rarely only with basal cell-specific immunostains
3 major patterns: Tufting, micropapillary, or flat
Cribriform morphology not within spectrum of HGPIN
Other uncommon types: Signet ring, mucinous, foamy, inverted or hobnail, small cell (neuroendocrine)

Diagnostic Checklist.text: Screen for HGPIN on low-power magnification and confirm cytologic features on high-power view
If cytologic threshold for diagnosis is doubtful or borderline, probably not HGPIN
If features exceed HGPIN, consider atypical intraductal proliferation or intraductal carcinoma
Dense cribriform morphology not considered HGPIN

Definitions.text: PIN: Preneoplastic process of epithelium lining restricted within prostatic ducts and aciniHistorically, low- and high-grade PIN (HGPIN) were recognized; currently only HGPIN is reported
sub_points: Historically, low- and high-grade PIN (HGPIN) were recognized; currently only HGPIN is reported

Definitions.text: HGPIN: Pronounced nuclear atypia, similar to carcinoma, with varied architectural patterns, confined to acini or ducts

Genetics.text: Provides evidence of association between HGPIN and prostate carcinoma (PCa)
TMPRSS::ERGfusionSeen in 19% of HGPIN intermingling with cancer foci vs. 48.5% for clinically localized PCaMuch less common in HGPIN cases not associated with invasive carcinoma
sub_points: Seen in 19% of HGPIN intermingling with cancer foci vs. 48.5% for clinically localized PCa
Much less common in HGPIN cases not associated with invasive carcinoma

Genetics.text: Aneuploid DNA seen in 32-58% of cases
Nuclear morphometric studies show characteristics intermediate between cancer and benign glands
Deletions of chromosome 8p most common allelic loss, detected in both HGPIN and adenocarcinoma

3D Modeling.text: Overall acinar organization with short tubular and saccular outpouchings, connected to adjacent glands
Basal cells present mostly as compact sheets; may be only scattered in some regions

Localization.text: Most frequently, location is peripheral zone of prostateRarely can be detected in central and transition zones
sub_points: Rarely can be detected in central and transition zones

Incidence.text: Diagnosed in ~ 5% of needle biopsies
Present in nearly all prostate glands harboring adenocarcinoma vs. 43% of age-matched controls

Age.text: May be seen as early as 3rd decade; incidence increases with age, reaching up to 67% by 8th decade

Ethnicity.text: More diffuse and develop earlier in Black compared to White patients

Presentation.text: Asymptomatic, commonly encountered as incidental histologic finding
May have abnormal serum PSA level

Treatment.text: Risk of cancerWith extended sampling biopsy, HGPIN is associated with ~ 25% risk of finding PCa in subsequent biopsyMultifocal (i.e., > 3 cores), bilateral HGPIN and that associated with atypical foci have higher risk of harboring concomitant PCaClose follow-up may be needed in high-risk casesRepeat extended biopsy within 6 months; more sampling of affected region may be performed~ 90% of cancers diagnosed following HGPIN detected in 1st or 2nd repeat biopsies
sub_points: With extended sampling biopsy, HGPIN is associated with ~ 25% risk of finding PCa in subsequent biopsy

Multifocal (i.e., > 3 cores), bilateral HGPIN and that associated with atypical foci have higher risk of harboring concomitant PCaClose follow-up may be needed in high-risk casesRepeat extended biopsy within 6 months; more sampling of affected region may be performed~ 90% of cancers diagnosed following HGPIN detected in 1st or 2nd repeat biopsies
Close follow-up may be needed in high-risk cases
Repeat extended biopsy within 6 months; more sampling of affected region may be performed
~ 90% of cancers diagnosed following HGPIN detected in 1st or 2nd repeat biopsies

Surgical approaches.text: Not needed for isolated HGPIN unless concomitant adenocarcinoma is documented

Ultrasonographic Findings.text: May be associated with hypoechoic lesion in peripheral zone, indistinguishable from carcinoma

General Features.text: Not associated with recognizable gross findings

Sections to Be Submitted.text: If only HGPIN (without invasive foci) detected in transurethral resectionSubmit entire specimen for histologic evaluation &/or obtain deeper levels of block with HGPINBiopsy of peripheral zone may be option, particularly in younger males
sub_points: Submit entire specimen for histologic evaluation &/or obtain deeper levels of block with HGPIN
Biopsy of peripheral zone may be option, particularly in younger males

Sections to Be Submitted.text: If only HGPIN (without invasive foci) detected in prostate needle biopsy specimenMay consider deeper levels if extensive or associated with atypical small acinar proliferation
sub_points: May consider deeper levels if extensive or associated with atypical small acinar proliferation

sub_points: Hyperchromasia
Nuclear overlap
