Histologic Features.text: Preserved or discontinuous basal cell layer; may be readily visible on routine slides or only with basal cell markers

3 major architectural patterns of HGPIN existTufting: Acinar cell stratification with luminal undulationMicropapillary: Slender filiform projections and buddingFlat: Lacks cellular stratification (1 or 2 cell layers)Cribriformpattern for HGPIN was recognized in past, but recent recommendations argue against itContains complex intraductal proliferation resulting in multiple irregular or round, punched-out luminaMay be difficult to distinguish from other more potentially clinically significant intraductal proliferations with more complex architecture and atypia that fall short of intraductal carcinoma; currently recommended "atypical intraductal proliferation"Many pathologists do not diagnose cribriform HGPIN on needle biopsyOptional to call cribriform HGPIN on radical prostatectomy, but usually represents part of spectrum of intraductal carcinoma
sub_points: Tufting: Acinar cell stratification with luminal undulation
Micropapillary: Slender filiform projections and budding
Flat: Lacks cellular stratification (1 or 2 cell layers)

Cribriformpattern for HGPIN was recognized in past, but recent recommendations argue against itContains complex intraductal proliferation resulting in multiple irregular or round, punched-out luminaMay be difficult to distinguish from other more potentially clinically significant intraductal proliferations with more complex architecture and atypia that fall short of intraductal carcinoma; currently recommended "atypical intraductal proliferation"Many pathologists do not diagnose cribriform HGPIN on needle biopsyOptional to call cribriform HGPIN on radical prostatectomy, but usually represents part of spectrum of intraductal carcinoma
Contains complex intraductal proliferation resulting in multiple irregular or round, punched-out lumina

May be difficult to distinguish from other more potentially clinically significant intraductal proliferations with more complex architecture and atypia that fall short of intraductal carcinoma; currently recommended "atypical intraductal proliferation"
Many pathologists do not diagnose cribriform HGPIN on needle biopsy
Optional to call cribriform HGPIN on radical prostatectomy, but usually represents part of spectrum of intraductal carcinoma

sub_points: Signet ring, mucinous, foamy, inverted/hobnail, small cell

Histologic Features.text: Multiple patterns frequently seen concurrently
These patterns have no clinical significance but are important for differential diagnosis with mimics

Variety of other architectural and cytologic features may be observed in HGPINLuminal cytoplasmic blebs, epithelial arches, cellular trabecular epithelial bars, "Roman bridges," partial gland involvement, and basal cell layer disruption with glandular buddingUncommonly, large cystic gland pattern, involvement in nodular hyperplasia and mucinous metaplasia

AMACR variably stains acinar cells (56-100%)
PSA/PSAP(+) in acinar cells
ERG may be positive in minority of cases
PTEN expression generally retained

Intraductal Carcinoma of Prostate.text: More recognized entity now but still associated with some controversy, particularly regarding nomenclature when it is exclusive finding in needle core biopsy, and whether (or how) to grade it
Suggested to represent either intraductal or intraacinar spread of invasive adenocarcinoma or intraluminal carcinomatous progression of HGPIN
TMPRSS::ERGfusion more common in IDC-P than HGPIN
PTEN loss more common in IDC-P (PTEN retained in HGPIN)Retained PTEN expression does not exclude IDC-P
sub_points: Retained PTEN expression does not exclude IDC-P

Intraductal Carcinoma of Prostate.text: Similar loss of heterozygosity seen with Gleason patterns 4 and 5 adenocarcinoma
Multivariate analysis confirms independent adverse prognostic value of intraductal carcinoma over Gleason grade, stage, tumor volume, and treatment failure

Proposed criteria for diagnosing IDC-P vis-à-vis HGPINDense cribriform glandsDefined as > 50% of gland composed of epithelium relative to luminal spacesSolid nests (filling the gland)Marked nuclear pleomorphismNo specific size criterion but primarily markedly pleomorphic nuclear atypiaNecrosis, particularly comedonecrosis
sub_points: Dense cribriform glandsDefined as > 50% of gland composed of epithelium relative to luminal spaces
Defined as > 50% of gland composed of epithelium relative to luminal spaces
Solid nests (filling the gland)

Intraductal Carcinoma of Prostate.text: Basal cell layer is present, similar to HGPIN; often continuous and prominent
Without invasive foci, may be impossible to differentiate vs. HGPIN in limited biopsy material or when not extensive
Most cases with follow-up show invasive carcinoma in rebiopsy or prostatectomy
Closely associated with large volume and high-grade invasive adenocarcinoma (Gleason pattern 4 or 5)

Atypical Intraductal Proliferation.text: Intraductal proliferation with more complex architectural &/or cytologic atypia than typical for HGPIN but falling short of strict diagnostic threshold for IDC-PLoose cribriforming (lumina > epithelium)Solid or dense cribriforming incompletely filling lumenNo significant nuclear pleomorphism or necrosisSome such cases would have been within spectrum of cribriform HGPIN
sub_points: Loose cribriforming (lumina > epithelium)
Solid or dense cribriforming incompletely filling lumen
No significant nuclear pleomorphism or necrosis
Some such cases would have been within spectrum of cribriform HGPIN

PIN-Like Adenocarcinoma.text: Some adenocarcinomas may have stratified epithelium and may form medium-sized glands
Numerous atypical glands with absence of basal cell layer; may be associated with typical acinar pattern

High-Grade Acinar Adenocarcinoma With Cr.text: Greater architectural complexity, including confluent cribriforming, back-to-back glands, and solid nests
Absent basal cell layer with IHC

Ductal Adenocarcinoma.text: Commonly involves prostatic urethra and periurethral region, but involvement may be throughout prostate
Papillae contain true fibrovascular stalks; no maturation
Nuclei frequently pseudostratified with elongated appearance; mitoses may be frequent
Invasive features present (crowded back-to-back glands, stromal fibrosis, perineural invasion, extraprostatic extension)
Majority lacks basal cell layer (confirmed by basal cell markers)

Prostate Central Zone Glands.text: Architecturally complex (cribriforming, roman bridge) but lacks nuclear changes of HGPIN

Benign Prostate Hyperplasia Nodule With.text: Located in transition zone, background BPH
Architectural complexity but lacks atypical cytology

Cribriform Hyperplasia.text: Frequently clear cytoplasm with no amphophilia
Lack of nuclear changes of HGPIN

Prostate Glands With Reactive Atypia (In.text: Need more stringent criteria for HGPIN or should be questioned in areas of infarction, inflammation, or previously radiated glands

Transitional Cell Metaplasia.text: Multilayered cells or solid nests without patterns of HGPIN
Uniform, elongated cells with nuclear grooves; secretory cell layer may be focally present

Atypical Basal Cell Hyperplasia.text: Atypical nuclei in basal and not secretory cells; usually, architectural patterns of HGPIN absent

Low-Grade Acinar Adenocarcinoma.text: Small glands adjacent to HGPIN may be challengingDifficult to distinguish adjacent true invasive adenocarcinoma from tangentially sectioned outpouchings of HGPIN
sub_points: Difficult to distinguish adjacent true invasive adenocarcinoma from tangentially sectioned outpouchings of HGPIN

Low-Grade Acinar Adenocarcinoma.text: Immunostains are useful only if basal cells are demonstrated in small glands, indicating outpouching
Even in absence of basal cell markers, small glands could still represent HGPIN, as basal cell layer usually discontinuous or markedly attenuated
Such cases may be diagnosed as HGPIN with atypical focus suspicious, but not diagnostic, for carcinoma

Basal Cell/Adenoid Cystic Carcinoma.text: Basaloid-appearing cells with smaller nuclei with adenoid cystic pattern and infiltrative architecture
Basement membrane material may be present

Urothelial Carcinoma Involving Prostatic.text: Significant cellular pleomorphism and mitotic activity within large glandular structures
Cytoplasm densely eosinophilic and may appear squamoid
Immunostains can help establish diagnosis [PSA/PSAP negative; p63, HMWCK (34βE12) positive]
Clinical history of urothelial carcinoma often present

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Screen for HGPIN on low-power magnification and confirm cytologic features on high-power view
If cytologic threshold for diagnosis is doubtful or borderline, probably not HGPIN
If features exceed HGPIN, consider atypical intraductal proliferation or intraductal carcinoma
Dense cribriform morphology not considered HGPIN

Key Elements to Report.text: Associated atypical small acinar proliferation, suspicious for invasive carcinoma
Number of biopsy cores involved by HGPIN and extent of involvement (e.g., isolated, focal, multifocal, extensive)
Presence or absence of concomitant adenocarcinoma

sub_points: Quantitatively &/or qualitatively insufficient for definitive diagnosis or exclusion of prostatic carcinoma

Clinical Issues.text: Reported in 5% of prostate needle biopsies (0.7-9%)
Atypical small acinar proliferations (ASAP) diagnosis may prompt rebiopsy, including ASAP siteControversy over strength of this recommendation with contemporary biopsy protocols
sub_points: Controversy over strength of this recommendation with contemporary biopsy protocols

Clinical Issues.text: ASAP is associated with higher risk of finding prostate carcinoma (PCa) at rebiopsy (~ 40%) than benign or high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (HGPIN) diagnosis
Diagnosis/work-up of ASAP important in cases with limited low-grade PCa for risk stratification

Microscopic.text: Atypical small glands that are either too few in number or do not show sufficient atypia for definite diagnosis as PCa
IHC with AMACR and basal cell markers (HMWCK/34βE12; p63; p40) may be helpfulMindful of limitations and overlap between lesions in small foci/limited samplesERG IHC may be of value in select cases

Gleason Grading System.text: Widely accepted grading system for PCa

sub_points: Primary pattern is most prevalent pattern and secondary is 2nd most common pattern

Gleason Grading System.text: International Society of Urological Pathology (ISUP) proposed several modifications and guidelines in 2005, 2014, and 2019 and Genitourinary Pathology Society (GUPS) in 2019In needle biopsies, include tertiary pattern in GS if it is higher than secondary patternSimilar rule applies for transurethral resection and enucleation (simple prostatectomy) specimensIn high-grade cancers, ignore lower grade pattern if < 5% (e.g., 4 + 4, if pattern 3 is < 5%)For cancers with > 1 pattern, include higher grade even if it is < 5% (e.g., 3 + 4, even if pattern 4 is < 5%)Assign individual GS to all cores as aggregate if submitted in 1 container; assign GS to each core separately designated (e.g., ink or separately submitted) by urologistIn radical prostatectomy, provide GS (primary and secondary pattern); separately mention tertiary patternTertiary pattern upgraded as secondary pattern if > 5%Assign separate GS to dominant tumor(s) for multifocal tumors in radical prostatectomyIndividualized Gleason grading approach for some PCa morphologic variants and subtypes

Terminology.text: Adenocarcinoma of prostatic epithelial cell origin with large glandular cribriform or papillary architectures lined by tall columnar cells, often with pseudostratified growth

Majority of patients have elevated serum PSA level

Centrally located tumors can have exophytic friable fronds protruding in urethral lumen

Microscopic.text: Main architectural patterns:Papillary,cribriform, andsolid

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: PIN-like prostate cancer, HGPIN, prostatic polyp

Synonyms.text: PIN-like ductal adenocarcinoma: Adenocarcinoma with stratified epithelium (not believed to be ductal cancer)

Definitions.text: Invasive adenocarcinoma of prostatic epithelial cell origin with large glandular, papillary or cribriform architecture lined by tall columnar cells, often with pseudostratified growth and significant cytologic atypia
Features comprising predominant (> 80%) or pure histology of carcinoma in TURP or radical prostatectomy
Occurs either (rarely) as pure or (more commonly) in combination with acinar adenocarcinoma

Origin.text: Previously postulated to arise from prostatic utricle (once thought to be müllerian-derived) due to its morphologic resemblance to adenocarcinoma of endometrium

Incidence.text: Pure ductal adenocarcinoma accounts for ~ 1-3% of all prostate cancers
Mixed ductal and acinar adenocarcinoma reported in ~ 5% of prostate cancers

Age.text: Median: 65-67 years; similar to acinar adenocarcinoma

Site.text: May be peripheral &/or central in location
Peripheral tumors involve prostate peripheral zone and can extend to transition zone
Central tumors occur in periurethral area and involve transition zone and TURP specimens

Presentation.text: Peripherally located tumors: Elevated serum PSA levels, abnormal digital rectal examination
Central/periurethral tumors: Obstructive symptoms, hematuria
Bone metastasis are osteoblastic

Laboratory Tests.text: Majority of patients have elevated serum PSA; levels suggested to be higher compared than in acinar adenocarcinoma

Treatment.text: Surgical treatment for localized tumors
Multimodal therapy for advanced disease; optimal therapy for metastatic cases remains to be ascertained

Presence in biopsies indicate more advanced cancer at prostatectomy and shortened progression time than Gleason score (GS) ≤ 7 acinar adenocarcinoma

Metastasis at presentation seen in ~ 10% of cases, mostly to bones (88%), lymph nodes (62%), and lungs (19%)

Typically diffusely p63(+), HMWK (34βE12) (+), CK7(+), and CK20(+)

Basal Cell Carcinoma.text: Similar to SCC, tumor cells have scant cytoplasm, high nuclear:cytoplasmic ratio, and form nests, cords, or trabeculae
Typically diffusely (+) for basal cell markers [p63 and HMWK (34βE12)]

Gleason Grading.text: Not applicable for SCC or LCNEC
May be provided for admixed usual PCa component if mixed neuroendocrine carcinoma/usual PCa
Likely not applicable for areas of Paneth cell-like NED

Staging.text: AJCC Staging System applies for SCC of prostate

Adenoid Cystic (Basal Cell) Carcinoma of.name: Adenoid Cystic (Basal Cell) Carcinoma of Prostate

Terminology.text: Adenoid cystic (AC)/basal cell carcinoma (BCC)
Malignant neoplasm composed primarily of basaloid cells arising putatively from prostatic basal cells

Clinical Issues.text: Wide age range (28-89 years), but majority occur in older men
Most commonly presents with obstructive urinary symptoms
Normal serum PSA level
Local recurrence, metastasis, and death from disease reported in ~ 30-50% of cases

Macroscopic.text: White and fleshy tumor with ill-defined infiltrative edges, may have microcystic features
Tumor primarily centered in transition zone with variable peripheral zone and periprostatic involvement

Microscopic.text: Basaloid tumor cells have scant cytoplasm, high nuclear:cytoplasmic ratio, and irregular or angulated nuclei with open chromatin
Infiltration of adjacent parenchyma (diffuse, nonlobular growth) is hallmark feature for diagnosis of malignancy

2 main histologic patternsBCC pattern, consisting of variably sized solid nests, cords, or trabeculae with peripheral palisading of cellsAC carcinoma (ACC)-like pattern, consisting of infiltrative nests with prominent cribriform architecture
sub_points: BCC pattern, consisting of variably sized solid nests, cords, or trabeculae with peripheral palisading of cells
AC carcinoma (ACC)-like pattern, consisting of infiltrative nests with prominent cribriform architecture

Ancillary Tests.text: Basal cell markers (+) and usually PSA/PSAP(-)

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: AC pattern of basal cell hyperplasia
Anal cloacogenic carcinoma and ACC of Cowper glands

Synonyms.text: AC carcinoma (ACC), BCC, adenoid basal cell tumor, AC-like tumor of prostate

Definitions.text: Malignant neoplasm composed primarily of basaloid cells arising putatively from prostatic basal cells

Origin.text: Considered to arise from basal cells along prostatic ducts and acini
Recent series of 9 cases studied does not identify any rearrangements ofERGprotooncogene, unlike other prostate cancers
Up to 50% harbor t(6;9)MYB::NFIBtranslocations seen in ACC of salivary, skin adnexa, or lung

Incidence.text: Uncommon: ~ 75 cases reported in literature

Age.text: Wide age range (28-89 years), but majority occur in older men

Presentation.text: Most commonly presents with obstructive urinary symptomsMost cases diagnosed on transurethral resection of prostate (TURP) specimens
sub_points: Most cases diagnosed on transurethral resection of prostate (TURP) specimens

Presentation.text: Perianal pain
Few examples incidentally encountered in needle biopsy during work-up for elevated serum PSA level for other causes

Laboratory Tests.text: Serum PSA levels may be normal, elevated if coincident conventional prostate carcinoma

Treatment.text: Most reported cases treated with TURP with subset undergoing radical prostatectomy
Advanced stage treated with adjuvant radiotherapy or chemotherapy

Prognosis.text: Limited data available on clinical behavior
Local recurrence, metastasis, and death from disease reported in ~ 30-50% of cases
Metastases commonly to lung and liver
Bone metastasis rare compared to acinar adenocarcinoma
Presence of large solid nests with central necrosis, high Ki-67 staining, and less immunoreactivity to basal cell markers suggested to be associated with aggressive behavior

General Features.text: White and fleshy grossly apparent tumor with ill-defined infiltrative edges
May have microcystic features

Site of Involvement.text: Tumor widely involving prostate, including peripheral zone; many invade bladder neck or periprostatic adipose tissue

Histologic Features.text: Basaloid tumor cells have scant cytoplasm, high nuclear:cytoplasmic ratio, and irregular or angulated nuclei with open chromatin
Basaloid cells may exhibit nuclear and cytoplasmic microvacuolation
Infiltration of adjacent parenchyma (diffuse nonlobular growth) is hallmark feature of BCC
BCC-like patternVariably sized solid nests, cords, or trabeculae with peripheral palisading of basaloid cellsMay be associated with extensive central necrosis
sub_points: Variably sized solid nests, cords, or trabeculae with peripheral palisading of basaloid cells
May be associated with extensive central necrosis

Histologic Features.text: ACC-like patternTumor grows in nests with prominent cribriform architectureEosinophilic, hyaline, basement membrane-like material may be presentBasophilic mucinous secretions may be present in lumina
sub_points: Tumor grows in nests with prominent cribriform architecture
Eosinophilic, hyaline, basement membrane-like material may be present
Basophilic mucinous secretions may be present in lumina

Histologic Features.text: Additionally, tubuloglandular pattern with collagenous rim and basal cell hyperplasia (BCH)-like patterns may occur
Combination of these different architectural patterns is often (> 80%) encountered
Usually associated with desmoplastic stromal response, which may be fibromyxoid or myxoid
Rarely acinar, sebaceous, or squamous cell differentiation may be present
Perineural invasion, angiolymphatic invasion, or necrosis may be present
Currently, there is no grading system for these tumors
Extraprostatic extension is present in majority of cases, involving bladder neck, adipose tissue, or seminal vesicle
Tumor involvement of thick bladder neck muscles detected in most TURP specimens
Subset may have synchronous or metachronous prostate cancer, such as acinar adenocarcinoma, sarcomatoid carcinoma, or small cell carcinoma

Immunohistochemistry.text: Usually PSA/PSAP(-), or at most focally (+), subset AR(+), all ERG(-)
Basal cell markers (+), including p63 or HMWCK (34βE12)May stain multiple layers of cells, only peripheral aspect of tumor clusters, or in only few scattered tumor cells
sub_points: May stain multiple layers of cells, only peripheral aspect of tumor clusters, or in only few scattered tumor cells

Immunohistochemistry.text: Typically CK20(-)/CK7(+)CK7 exhibits luminal (+) staining in ACC pattern, inverse to HMWCK (34βE12), which stains peripheral aspectCK7(-) in pure solid basal cell nests
sub_points: CK7 exhibits luminal (+) staining in ACC pattern, inverse to HMWCK (34βE12), which stains peripheral aspect
CK7(-) in pure solid basal cell nests

Immunohistochemistry.text: Only minority (27%) of tumors are AMACR(+)
Variable proportions of cells stain for p53 in 2/3 of cases
Synaptophysin (-/+), chromogranin (-)
BCL2 staining is strongly and diffusely (+)
High proliferative rate with Ki-67 nuclear staining, > 20% (+)

Adenoid Cystic Pattern of Basal Cell Hyp.text: Occurs in background of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and BCH
When florid, may mimic BCC but does not show invasion
Cribriform architecture may be present; glands typically smaller
Many previously reported BCC may correspond to exuberant examples of AC pattern of BCH (AC-BCH)
Exhibits nodular, well-circumscribed or lobulocentric growth, predominantly in transition zone
In contrast to orderly arranged clusters of BCH, BCC shows haphazard, widespread, or single gland infiltration

Distinction from BCC based mainly on absence of invasive featuresAbsent desmoplasia, perineural invasion, or necrosis; stroma is cellular as in BPHLack of infiltration between normal prostatic glands or extraprostatic extension
sub_points: Absent desmoplasia, perineural invasion, or necrosis; stroma is cellular as in BPH
Lack of infiltration between normal prostatic glands or extraprostatic extension

Adenoid Cystic Pattern of Basal Cell Hyp.text: Luminal aspect of AC-BCH is bounded by acinar cells
BCL2 stains more diffusely and strongly in BCC than BCH
Ki-67 usually labels > 20% of cells in BCC vs. < 5% in BCH

Acinar Adenocarcinoma of Prostate With A.text: Rare examples of acinar prostatic adenocarcinoma demonstrate diffuse, aberrant nuclear expression of p63
These cancers may be encountered on prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN) cocktail work-up of small foci or carcinomas with variant morphology
Such carcinomas may also demonstrate basaloid or atrophic morphology
Some cases with multilayered or spindled cytomorphology
Infiltrative architecture with small gland pattern
These cases are HMWCK(-), as may be demonstrated on single stain for this antibody

Small Cell Carcinoma.text: Sheets of small cells with high nuclear:cytoplasmic ratio exhibiting nests, cords, or trabecular growth
Nuclear molding, salt and pepper chromatin, abundant single cell necrosis, and crush artifact
Neuroendocrine markers (+) and basal cell markers (-)

Poorly Differentiated Acinar Adenocarcin.text: High-grade adenocarcinoma composed of cribriform and solid nodules may mimic ACC
Often with markedly elevated serum PSA level

Cribriform Pattern Acinar Adenocarcinoma.text: May mimic ACC on low magnification
Acinar cells have more cytoplasm and exhibit nucleomegaly with prominent nucleoli

Poorly Differentiated Urothelial Carcino.text: Invasive nests with cells containing abundant cytoplasm and higher degree of pleomorphism
Carcinoma in situ may be present along prostatic urethra, prostatic ducts, or bladder mucosa

Anal Cloacogenic Carcinoma and Adenoid C.text: Histologic and immunohistochemical overlap with BCC; cloacogenic carcinoma indistinguishable from BCC and ACC of Cowper glands similar to ACC of prostate
Distinction based on epicenter of tumor with prostate being only secondarily involved

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Infiltrative solid or cribriform nests of basaloid cells showing invasive features

Criteria.text: Gleason grading is not applicable for BCC and ACC of prostate

American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC.text: Though not specifically endorsed in AJCC prostate TNM system, it is widely used in reported literature

Classification.text: Urothelial carcinoma (UCa)of urinary bladder secondarily involving prostate: UCa arising primarily in bladder but extending to involve prostatic urethra or prostatic glandular parenchyma by either direct invasion, intraepithelial pagetoid spread, or by combination of these processes
Primary UCa of prostaterefers to either UCa arising primarily in prostatic urethra or arising in more distal, suburethral ducts and glands of prostate itself

Clinical Issues.text: UCa of urinary bladder secondarily involving prostateis relatively more common, ranging 12-58% at cystoprostatectomy
Primary UCa of prostateis uncommon, comprising 1-4% of prostate cancers in adults
Similar in age distribution to bladder UCa
Bladder UCa involving prostate presents due to bladder symptoms
Most primary prostatic UCa presents with obstructive symptoms

Definitions.text: PSS, low grade or high grade, is malignant cellular spindle cell lesion of specialized prostatic stroma with potential for local invasion or metastasis

Origin.text: PR is frequently expressed in STUMP and PSS, supporting derivation from hormonally responsive mesenchyme of prostate

Leiomyosarcoma is most common sarcoma involving adult prostate
Leiomyosarcoma varies from those resembling smooth muscle cells with moderate atypia and increased mitotic activity to pleomorphic tumors

May arise primarily from prostate or from pelvis with secondary involvement of prostate

Unlike prostatic phyllodes tumor, epithelial component is PSA and PAP (-)

Clinical Issues.text: Seen in 5.6% of male autopsies with malignancies and 0.2% of prostate resections and biopsies
Mostly encountered as incidental autopsy findings
Involvement of prostate by metastasis indicates late or widely disseminated stage of disease

Rarely, GI stromal tumors may invade into prostate and present as intraprostatic mass

Imaging.text: Radiologic work-up helpful in investigating unknown primary origin

Distinction important due to differing therapies (i.e., hormonal for prostate cancer, chemotherapy for bladder cancer, and radiotherapy for rectal cancer)

Terminology.text: Germ cell aplasia
All azoospermias in which seminiferous epithelium consists of only Sertoli cells

Clinical Issues.text: Infertility, azoospermia, &/or hypogonadism
Usually present between ages 20-40 years for evaluation of infertility
5-10% of infertile men are due to Sertoli cell-only syndrome
Well-developed secondary male sexual characteristics
Normal virilization with no gynecomastia
Gonadotropins may be increased or decreased depending on type of syndrome

Macroscopic.text: Testes are usually normal, smaller, or atrophic

Definitions.text: All azoospermias in which seminiferous tubules lack germ cells and contain Sertoli cells only

Developmental Anomaly.text: Sertoli cell-only syndrome with immature Sertoli cells caused by deficiency of both FSH and LH

Sertoli cell-only syndrome with dysgenetic Sertoli cells has Sertoli cells that proceed to pubertal maturation but variably deviate from normal maturationAssociated with cryptorchidism, Y chromosome abnormalities, Klinefelter syndrome (47XXY), and idiopathic infertility
sub_points: Associated with cryptorchidism, Y chromosome abnormalities, Klinefelter syndrome (47XXY), and idiopathic infertility

Developmental Anomaly.text: Sertoli cell-only syndrome with mature Sertoli cells is thought to be due to failure of migration of germ cells

Environmental Exposure.text: Sertoli cell-only syndrome with involuting Sertoli cells may be secondary to irradiation, cytotoxic therapy, hormonal therapy for prostate cancer, chemical/toxin exposure, and viral infection
Sertoli cell-only syndrome with dedifferentiated Sertoli cells is associated with androgen deprivation therapy, estrogen treatment for transsexuality, and platinum chemotherapy agents

Presentation.text: Infertility, azoospermia, &/or hypogonadism
5-10% of infertility in men is due to Sertoli cell-only syndrome
Well-developed secondary male sexual characteristics with no gynecomastia

Laboratory Tests.text: Gonadotropins may be increased or decreased depending on type of syndrome
Most common types (dysgenetic, adult, and involuting) have elevated FSH, normal or elevated LH, and normal or decreased testosterone
Immature type has decreased FSH and LH beginning in childhood

Treatment.text: No known effective treatment options
Immature Sertoli cell type may be treated with hormone therapy to recover some degree of spermatogenesis
Secondary Sertoli cell-only syndrome may be reversible after elimination of specific etiology

Prognosis.text: Extensive fine-needle aspiration may recover some spermatozoa in some types

General Features.text: Testes are normal, small, or atrophic

Terminology.text: Inflammatory process of testis or epididymis due to microorganisms (bacteria, fungus, virus, etc.)

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Bacteria, virus, fungus or parasites

Clinical Issues.text: Painful mass or swelling
Fever and other systemic signs of infection
Mumps orchitis occurs in 15-30% of adult cases but is rare before puberty
Surgery is not indicated unless infarction occurs

Macroscopic.text: General enlargement of testicle
Mass lesion with pus, hemorrhagic cut surface

Microscopic.text: Variable mixed acute, chronic, or granulomatous inflammation
Abscess formation and seminiferous tubule necrosis
Acute bacterial orchitis causes abscesses with acute inflammation
Syphilitic orchitis is usually granulomatous and has abundant plasma cells
Mump orchitis characterized by interstitial edema, vascular congestion, inflammatory infiltrate consisting mainly of lymphocytes and plasma cells
Fungal infection characterized by mixed inflammation ± necrosis

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Seminoma or other germ cell neoplasm

Definitions.text: Inflammatory process of testis or epididymis due to microorganisms (bacteria, fungus, virus, etc.)

Incidence.text: High in developing countries, immigrants, and immunocompromised patients

Age.text: Affects any age but mainly adults (> 72% are older than 35 yr)

Treatment.text: Surgical resection and systemic antituberculous therapy

Prognosis.text: Excellent with modern antituberculous treatment

Epididymis is almost always primary site of involvement with secondary spread to testis

When testis is involved, swollen and nodular
Late stages: Extensive cystic change due to necrosis

Multiple confluent granulomas with central caseating necrosis
Aggregates of epithelioid cells with peripheral rim of lymphocytes
Langhans giant cells (fusion of epithelioid cells with nuclei arranged in horseshoe-shaped pattern, often pointing toward necrosis)
Schaumann (basophilic, shell-like, lamellated calcified conchoidal bodies) and asteroid bodies may be present

Other Infectious Granulomatous Epididymo.text: Organisms may be visualized with GMS or PAS stains

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Confluent caseating granulomas

90% can be palpable in inguinal canal (10% in abdomen or nonexistent, truly hidden, or anorchia)
Most will descend into scrotum without any intervention during 1st year of life
Medical or surgical correction are both effective

Macroscopic.text: Abnormal location and usually smaller sized testis than normal or contralateral testis

Microscopic.text: Variable degrees of decreased diameter of seminiferous tubules
Tubules with hypospermatogenesis to complete lack of spermatogenesis (resembling Sertoli cell-only syndrome)

Thickening and hyalinization of tubular basement membranes and interstitial edema

Definitions.text: 1 or both testes present outside scrotum with failure to descend into scrotum (empty scrotum)

Developmental Anomaly.text: Defect in fetal androgens or excess maternal estrogen
Associated with congenital malformation syndromes, such as Prader-Willi, Noonan, and cloacal exstrophy

Acquired Cryptorchidism.text: Postoperative trapped testis (iatrogenic) or spontaneous ascent

Incidence.text: Most common birth defect of male genitalia
3% of full-term newborns have undescended testis/testes
1% of infants have incompletely descended testes 12 months after birth
More common in premature infants (30% of boys born before 30 weeks gestational age)
True cryptorchidism accounts for 25% of cases of empty scrotum

Presentation.text: No particular symptoms; empty scrotal sac usually detected by parents
~ 2/3 unilateral and 1/3 bilateral
90% may be palpable in inguinal canal (10% in abdomen or nonexistent, truly hidden, or anorchia)
Testis may be found anywhere along path of descent from retroperitoneum to inguinal ring
Rarely located outside of path of descent (ectopic), such as outside of inguinal canal, perineum, opposite scrotum, femoral canal, or under skin

Histologic Features.text: Variable degree of decreased diameter of seminiferous tubules
Tubules with hypospermatogenesis to complete lack of spermatogenesis (resembling Sertoli cell-only syndrome)
Presence of ring-shaped tubules or megatubules

Interstitial (Leydig cells) cells usually spared and may show hyperplasia or Pick adenoma (Sertoli cell nodule)

Presence of eosinophilic bodies or microliths
May have dysgenetic features with nondescriptive undifferentiated sex cord-stromal tissue and nests resembling that of immature seminiferous tubules

sub_points: Sampling and immunohistochemistry may be necessary

Terminology.text: Proliferation of uncommitted neoplastic germ cells within atrophic seminiferous tubules located at periphery of tubulesRecent favored term germ cell neoplasia in situ (GCNIS)
sub_points: Recent favored term germ cell neoplasia in situ (GCNIS)

Negative for cytokeratin, α-fetoprotein, CD30 (BerH2) (may be positive in intratubular embryonal carcinoma)

Definitions.text: Proliferation of uncommitted neoplastic germ cells within usually atrophic seminiferous tubules, aligned at periphery of tubules; may be associated with focal or absent spermatogenesis

Incidence.text: Present in ipsilateral uninvolved testis in 80-95% of patients with seminoma or nonseminomatous germ cell tumors

Treatment.text: Unilateral GCNIS usually managed by active surveillance or orchiectomy
Bilateral GCNIS may be treated by orchiectomy or radiation

Prognosis.text: May progress to seminomatous or nonseminomatous germ cell tumors in ~ 50% of cases within 5 years

General Features.text: Usually no abnormalities or microlithiasis on ultrasound
No demonstrable testicular mass; testis size may be normal or smaller

Tubules with decreased or absent spermatogenesis
May be associated with microlithiasis

May be associated with vascularized scar (regression)

Predominant Cell/Compartment Type.text: Germ cells, uncommitted atypical germ cells, seminomatous/undifferentiated

Spermatocytic Seminoma (Intratubular).text: Polymorphic cells (3 different cell types) in center of seminiferous tubules; no peripheral localization

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Large atypical cells with clear cytoplasm in atrophic tubules with decreased or no spermatogenesis

Terminology.text: Malignant germ cell tumor composed of relatively uniform cells with abundant clear cytoplasm, well-defined cell borders, and nuclei with 1 or more prominent nucleoli

Clinical Issues.text: Most common malignant testicular germ cell tumor (~ 50%)

Macroscopic.text: Well circumscribed and homogeneous ± lobulation
Gray-white, tan, creamy, fleshy or firm, often bulging cut surface; rare hemorrhage or necrosis

Microscopic.text: Fibrous septa divide sheets or nests of tumor cells into lobules
Large round-polygonal tumor cells with abundant clear cytoplasm
Tumor cells are evenly spread without nuclear overlap in well-fixed tissues
Prominent cytoplasmic membranes (distinct cell boundaries)
Lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate, occasionally extensive with germinal centers in fibrous septa
Ill-defined granuloma formation in ~ 50-60%; may be extensive, which may create diagnostic difficulty in recognizing tumor cells

Ancillary Tests.text: Positive for PLAP, OCT3/OCT4, CD117, Podoplanin (D2-40), vimentin, SALL4, NANOG, SOX17
Negative for cytokeratin (may be focal or weak), EMA, α-fetoprotein, HCG, inhibin-α, CD30, glypican-3, SOX2

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Embryonal carcinoma, yolk sac tumor, monophasic choriocarcinoma, lymphoma, spermatocytic seminoma, Sertoli cell tumor, nonspecific granulomatous orchitis

Definitions.text: Malignant germ cell tumor composed of relatively uniform cells with abundant clear cytoplasm, well-defined cell borders, and nuclei with 1 or more prominent nucleoli

Incidence.text: Most common malignant testicular germ cell tumor (~ 50%)

Age.text: Most common in men 35-45 yr old, uncommon in men over 50 yr, and rare in children; mean: 5-10 yr older than nonseminomatous germ cell tumors

Presentation.text: Most commonly painless testicular mass (70%)
Other presentations: Scrotal pain (10%), symptoms of metastasis (10%), asymptomatic (4%), gynecomastia and exophthalmos (rare)
Mostly unilateral and rarely bilateral (~ 2%); bilaterality more common than in nonseminomatous germ cell tumors
Spermatic cord involvement (rarer than in nonseminomatous germ cell tumors; < 5%)

Laboratory Tests.text: Serum markers may be elevatedSerum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG)
sub_points: Serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)
Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG)

sub_points: AFP elevation in patient with pure seminoma is clinically treated as nonseminomatous germ cell tumor

Treatment.text: For patients with stage I seminoma 3 options are availableRadical inguinal orchiectomy and surveillance with measurement of serum markers, chest x-ray, and CT of abdomen and pelvisRadical inguinal orchiectomy with radiation therapyRadical inguinal orchiectomy followed by either 1 or 2 doses of carboplatin adjuvant therapy
sub_points: Radical inguinal orchiectomy and surveillance with measurement of serum markers, chest x-ray, and CT of abdomen and pelvis
Radical inguinal orchiectomy with radiation therapy
Radical inguinal orchiectomy followed by either 1 or 2 doses of carboplatin adjuvant therapy

Treatment.text: For patients with stage II seminomaRadical inguinal orchiectomy followed by radiation therapy to retroperitoneal and ipsilateral pelvic lymph nodes, or combination chemotherapy
sub_points: Radical inguinal orchiectomy followed by radiation therapy to retroperitoneal and ipsilateral pelvic lymph nodes, or combination chemotherapy

Treatment.text: For patients with stage III seminomaRadical inguinal orchiectomy followed by multidrug (bleomycin, etoposide, and cisplatin) chemotherapy
sub_points: Radical inguinal orchiectomy followed by multidrug (bleomycin, etoposide, and cisplatin) chemotherapy

Prognosis.text: Excellent prognosis with 98% cure rate for stage I or II seminoma
Associated with pathologic stage, tumor size, rete testis invasion, and intertubular growth > 3 HPFs distance from main mass
Lymphovascular invasion is important prognostic factor in univariate analysis but not independent prognostic factor
Concept of anaplastic seminoma (> 3 mitoses per HPF) is not accepted as separate entity or adverse prognostic factor

General Features.text: Well circumscribed and homogeneous ± lobulation; 90% confined to testis
Gray-white, tan, creamy, fleshy or firm, often bulging cut surface; usually no hemorrhage or necrosisTumors with hemorrhage and necrosis often indicate nonseminomatous components or in large tumors
sub_points: Tumors with hemorrhage and necrosis often indicate nonseminomatous components or in large tumors

General Features.text: May have geographic infarct-type necrosis (usually large tumors)
Punctate hemorrhage (usually in areas of syncytiotrophoblasts)
Small tumors may be difficult to see grossly; scar may be present in rare tumors
Rare spermatic cord invasion (< 5%)

Histologic Features.text: Main architectural growth patternsSolid sheets or nests (most common)Sclerotic or interstitial (in between seminiferous tubules; rare)Tubular, alveolar, trabecular, or pseudoglandular (rare)
sub_points: Solid sheets or nests (most common)
Sclerotic or interstitial (in between seminiferous tubules; rare)
Tubular, alveolar, trabecular, or pseudoglandular (rare)

Histologic Features.text: Fibrous septa divide sheets or nests of tumor cells into lobules
Tumor cells are evenly spread without nuclear overlap in well-fixed tissues
Lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate, occasionally extensive, with germinal centers in fibrous septa
Ill-defined granuloma formation in ~ 50-60%; may be extensive, which may create diagnostic difficulty in recognizing tumor cells
Fibrosis, sclerosis, and scar formation may be prominent (burnt-out seminoma when no tumor cells present)
Extensive hemorrhage and necrosis are rarely seen
Syncytiotrophoblastic giant cells may be seen in areas of hemorrhage; present in ~ 10-20% of tumors
Germ cell neoplasia in situ (GCNIS) in surrounding seminiferous tubules or pagetoid spread to rete testis

Cytologic Features.text: Large round-polygonal tumor cells with abundant clear cytoplasm
Prominent cytoplasmic membranes (distinct cell boundaries), no nuclear overlapping
Relatively uniform, large central nuclei with 1-2 prominent nucleoli
Mitotic figures range from few to frequent
Some tumors can have larger cells, high N:C ratio, and more mitoses (> 3/HPF); known as anaplastic seminoma
Rarely, tumor cells can have plasmacytoid, rhabdoid, or signet ring cell appearance

Predominant Cell/Compartment Type.text: Uncommitted large atypical malignant germ cells (primordial germ cells)

Histochemistry.text: Positive for periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) without diastase

Immunohistochemistry.text: Positive for PLAP, OCT3/OCT4, CD117, Podoplanin (D2-40), vimentin, SALL4, NANOG, SOX17
Negative for cytokeratin (may be focal or weak), EMA, α-fetoprotein, hCG, inhibin-α, CD30, glypican-3, SOX2

Embryonal Carcinoma, Solid Pattern.text: Usually admixed with glandular and papillary patterns
Marked cellular pleomorphism, vesicular nuclei, nuclear crowding with overlapping and indistinct cell borders, irregularly shaped nucleoli, frequent mitoses or apoptoses

Yolk Sac Tumor, Solid Pattern.text: Variable growth patterns, most commonly microcystic and reticular
Schiller-Duval bodies, basement membrane deposition, and hyaline globules are characteristic, if present
Positive for cytokeratin, α-fetoprotein, and glypican-3

Malignant Lymphoma.text: Usually older age group, history of lymphoma, frequent bilateral involvement, frequent spermatic cord involvement (> 40%)
Predominantly interstitial pattern of tumor cells between seminiferous tubules
Cytokeratin and germ cell markers negative; CD45 (LCA) and B- or T-cell markers positive (depending on type, B cell more common than T cell)

Spermatocytic Tumor.text: Older age group (> 50 yr with average of 56 yr)
Presence of 3 distinct types of tumor cells (small, intermediate, and large cells)
Lack of lymphocytic infiltration or granulomatous reaction; no fibrous septa; no association with GCNIS
Negative for PAS, germ cell tumor markers [PLAP, OCT3/OCT4, podoplanin (D2-40)]; SALL4 and CD117 may be positive

Monophasic Choriocarcinoma.text: Extremely rare; primary or metastatic foci postchemotherapy
Mononucleated tumor cells of variable sizes; more frequent associated hemorrhage and necrosis
Positive for hCG and human placental lactogen (HPL)

Sertoli Cell Tumor.text: Usually more prominent tubular or trabecular growth
Usually lack fibrous septa with lymphoplasmacytic and granulomatous reaction
Usually positive for α-inhibin, calretinin, and cytokeratin, negative for PLAP, podoplanin (D2-40), SALL4, and OCT3/OCT4

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Relatively uniform tumor cells with abundant clear cytoplasm, distinct cell boundaries, evenly spaced tumor cells without nuclear overlapping
Fibrous septa with lymphoplasmacytic infiltrates and granulomatous reaction

Diagnostically difficult situationsUnusual growth patterns: Tubular, pseudoglandular, or interstitialExtensive granulomatous reaction, sclerosis, or scar formation (regression)GCNIS with microinvasion (microscopic invasion)Poorly fixed tissue with artifact create more diagnostic problems
sub_points: Unusual growth patterns: Tubular, pseudoglandular, or interstitial
Extensive granulomatous reaction, sclerosis, or scar formation (regression)
GCNIS with microinvasion (microscopic invasion)
Poorly fixed tissue with artifact create more diagnostic problems

Key Elements to Report.text: General informationLaterality, multifocality, tumor size
sub_points: Laterality, multifocality, tumor size

Key Elements to Report.text: Histologic type (pure, classic, or with other components)
Pathologic stage (pTNM): Tumor extension, regional lymph node status, and distant metastasis
Rete testis stromal invasion, not just pagetoid extension
Margin status (spermatic cord and other)
Venous/lymphatic vessel invasion
Additional pathologic findings (GCNIS, syncytiotrophoblastic cells, scar, etc.), if present

Terminology.text: Germ cell tumor composed of undifferentiated cells of epithelial appearance with marked cytologic anaplasia and variety of growth patterns

Clinical Issues.text: 2nd most common pure testicular germ cell neoplasm after seminoma (~ 10%)
Age ranges from 15-35 years (10 years younger than patients with seminoma)

Macroscopic.text: Often poorly circumscribed mass with more frequent extension to rete testis, epididymis, or spermatic cord (20%) than seminoma
Variegated cut surface with large areas of hemorrhage and necrosis

Microscopic.text: Pleomorphic tumor with 3 main growth patterns: Solid, glandular, and papillary
Large cohesive, highly pleomorphic tumor cells with moderate amount of amphophilic cytoplasm and indistinct cell membranes
Syncytial growth with nuclear overlapping with uneven cellular distribution, coarse or vesicular chromatin, prominent and irregular nucleoli
Frequent mitoses and apoptoses
Large areas of hemorrhage and necrosis common

Ancillary Tests.text: Positive for cytokeratin, CD30 (BerH2), OCT3/4, PLAP, SALL4, SOX2
Negative for EMA/MUC1, CEA, CK20, SOX17, glypican-3, α-inhibin, and calretinin

Definitions.text: Germ cell tumor composed of undifferentiated cells of epithelial appearance with marked cytologic anaplasia and variety of growth patterns

Incidence.text: 2nd most common pure testicular germ cell neoplasm after seminoma (~ 10%)
More commonly seen as mixed with other germ cell tumor components (~ 80%)

Age.text: 15-35 years (10 years younger than patients with seminoma)
Does not occur in infants or children; rare after 5th decade

Presentation.text: Testicular mass or swelling
Symptoms of metastasis, such as back pain, dyspnea, and neurologic symptoms
Elevated serum lactate dehydrogenase, PLAP, and CA19-9 may be seen
In pure EC, α-fetoprotein and β-hCG are not elevated

Treatment.text: Similar to other nonseminomatous germ cell tumors; depends mainly on clinical stage

Prognosis.text: Poorest among all germ cell tumors, worse than mixed germ cell tumor or seminoma
Prognosis closely correlated to clinical and pathologic stage of tumorCure rate > 95% for stage I, 70-85% for bulky stage II and stage III disease
sub_points: Cure rate > 95% for stage I, 70-85% for bulky stage II and stage III disease

Prognosis.text: More aggressive treatment with combined chemotherapy alone or in combination with retroperitoneal lymph node dissection following orchiectomy

General Features.text: Ultrasonography may detect mass lesion (typically ill-defined and heterogeneous) in testis
Often poorly circumscribed mass
Variegated cut surface with large areas of hemorrhage and necrosis

Size.text: Usually smaller than classic seminoma or mixed germ cell tumor

Histologic Features.text: Pleomorphic tumor with variety of growth patterns and often mixed patterns3 main growth patternsSolid, glandular, and papillaryOther less common patternsPseudopapillary, micropapillary, anastomosing/glandular, blastocyst-likeAppliqué pattern (central solid EC surrounded by peripheral degenerating tumor cells) may be seen2 rare distinctive patternsPolyembryoma-like and diffuse embryoma-like (not pure, examples of mixed germ cell tumor)
sub_points: 3 main growth patternsSolid, glandular, and papillary
Solid, glandular, and papillary
Other less common patternsPseudopapillary, micropapillary, anastomosing/glandular, blastocyst-like
Pseudopapillary, micropapillary, anastomosing/glandular, blastocyst-like
Appliqué pattern (central solid EC surrounded by peripheral degenerating tumor cells) may be seen
2 rare distinctive patternsPolyembryoma-like and diffuse embryoma-like (not pure, examples of mixed germ cell tumor)
Polyembryoma-like and diffuse embryoma-like (not pure, examples of mixed germ cell tumor)

Histologic Features.text: Hemorrhage and necrosis are common
Lymphocytic infiltrates may be seen, but granulomatous reaction is rare
More frequent lymphovascular invasion than seminoma
More frequent rete testis, epididymis, and spermatic cord invasion than other germ cell tumors
Germ cell neoplasia in situ (GCNIS) is commonly seen
Intratubular EC with comedo-type necrosis and calcifications may be seen

Cytologic Features.text: Large, cohesive, highly pleomorphic tumor cells with moderate amount of amphophilic cytoplasm and indistinct cell membranes
Syncytial growth with nuclear overlapping with uneven cellular distribution, coarse or vesicular chromatin, prominent and irregular nucleoli
Columnar cells with subnuclear or supranuclear cytoplasmic vacuoles in some glandular EC
Frequent mitoses and apoptoses with geographic areas of necrosis

Predominant Pattern/Injury Type.text: 3 main growth patternsSolid, glandular, and papillary
sub_points: Solid, glandular, and papillary

Predominant Cell/Compartment Type.text: Highly pleomorphic tumor cells with coarse or vesicular chromatin, prominent and irregular nucleoli

Immunohistochemistry.text: Positive for cytokeratin, CD30 (BerH2), OCT3/4, PLAP, SALL4, SOX2
May be focally positive for HCG or α-fetoprotein
Negative for EMA/MUC1, CEA, CK20, SOX17, glypican-3, α-inhibin, and calretinin

Seminoma (Anaplastic Seminoma).text: Sheets or lobules of tumor cells with less cytologic atypia and distinct cell borders
Presence of more prominent lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate or granulomas
Negative for CD30 (BerH2), SOX2, and cytokeratin (or focally positive)

Anaplastic Spermatocytic Tumor.text: Associated with classic area of spermatocytic tumor
Usually solid, occasionally micro- or macrocystic growth
Negative for CD30, cytokeratin, podoplanin (D2-40), PLAP, and OCT3/4

Yolk Sac Tumor (Solid or Papillary).text: Less atypical cells with more abundant cytoplasm, eosinophilic globules, and basement membrane material
Variety of growth patterns in same tumor
Negative for CD30 (BerH2), OCT3/4, or podoplanin (D2-40)

Metastatic Carcinoma.text: Occurs in older patients; clinical history of cancer
Positive for EMA/MUC1 and tissue-specific markers of metastatic origin
Negative for germ cell markers (OCT3/4, SALL4)

Malignant Lymphoma.text: Older age and more frequently bilateral (40%)
Tumor cells less cohesive and less pleomorphic than embryonal carcinoma
Positive for leukocyte common antigen and B- and T-cell markers

Sex Cord-Stromal Tumors.text: Tumor cells less pleomorphic, rare, or no mitoses
Positive for inhibin, calretinin, Melan-A (MART-1), and SF1
Negative for germ cell markers (OCT3/4, SALL4)

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Heterogeneous, epithelial growth with frequent solid, glandular, papillary, or other rare patterns
Highly anaplastic cytologic features of tumor cells
Frequent hemorrhage and tumor necrosis
Intratubular EC with comedonecrosis and coarse calcification

Key Elements To Report.text: Pure or mixed with other germ cell tumor components (if mixed, indicate relative percentage of each component)
Rete testis, spermatic cord, and tunica invasion
Presence of GCNIS, intratubular embryonal carcinoma, or syncytiotrophoblastic cells

Terminology.text: Germ cell tumor characterized by variety of growth patterns that recapitulate yolk sac, allantois, and extraembryonic mesenchyme

Clinical Issues.text: Most common germ cell tumor of infants and young children: No association with cryptorchidism (see separate chapter)
Pure form extremely rare in adults; usually present as component of mixed germ cell tumors

Microscopic.text: YST has multiple growth patterns with 1 or 2 dominant patterns or more frequently mixed patternsReticular or microcystic pattern most frequent (80%)Other common patterns include endodermal sinus, solid, papillary, and glandular
sub_points: Reticular or microcystic pattern most frequent (80%)
Other common patterns include endodermal sinus, solid, papillary, and glandular

Microscopic.text: Relatively uniform cells with clear or vacuolated to lightly eosinophilic cytoplasm
Bland cuboidal, columnar to flattened, or spindle cells
Presence of small, spherical, intracellular, or extracellular hyaline globules
Prominent basement membrane deposition

Ancillary Tests.text: Positive for cytokeratin, AFP, glypican-3, SALL4, PLAP (variable), SOX17 (variable)
Negative for CD30(Ber-H2), podoplanin (D2-40), OCT3/4, CD117, hCG, NANOG, inhibin-α, calretinin

Definitions.text: Germ cell tumor characterized by variety of growth patterns that recapitulate yolk sac, allantois, and extraembryonic mesenchyme

Incidence.text: Pure YST is most common testicular tumor of infants and young children (~ 75%)No association with cryptorchidism or other germ cell tumor components
sub_points: No association with cryptorchidism or other germ cell tumor components

Incidence.text: Pure YST is extremely rare (0.6%) in adult testesAt extragonadal sites, especially mediastinum, pure YST may occur
sub_points: At extragonadal sites, especially mediastinum, pure YST may occur

Incidence.text: YST is frequent component of mixed germ cell tumors (in ~ 40%)
YST is frequent tumor component after chemotherapy

Age.text: Mean: 25-35 years for adult YSTGenerally 10 years younger than patients with seminoma
sub_points: Generally 10 years younger than patients with seminoma

Presentation.text: Nonsymptomatic, rapid testicular enlargement
~ 90% of patients with childhood YST have clinical stage I disease
Presence of YST in adult patients with mixed germ cell tumor is frequently associated with lower stage presentation

Laboratory Tests.text: More than 95% patients have elevated serum α-fetoprotein (AFP)
Test for serum AFP is valuable tool in diagnosis and monitoring effectiveness of therapy

Treatment.text: For infants and children with pure YSTRadical inguinal orchiectomy for stage I tumor with close follow-up protocol (surveillance)Cisplatin-based therapy for relapse on surveillance, advanced stage disease, or metastasis
sub_points: Radical inguinal orchiectomy for stage I tumor with close follow-up protocol (surveillance)
Cisplatin-based therapy for relapse on surveillance, advanced stage disease, or metastasis

Treatment.text: For adult YST (usually mixed with other germ cell tumor)Similar to other nonseminomatous germ cell tumor based on clinical stageRadical inguinal orchiectomy ± retroperitoneal lymph node dissectionCisplatin-based chemotherapy for metastatic disease
sub_points: Similar to other nonseminomatous germ cell tumor based on clinical stage
Radical inguinal orchiectomy ± retroperitoneal lymph node dissection
Cisplatin-based chemotherapy for metastatic disease

Prognosis.text: Prognosis associated with clinical stage, lymphovascular invasion, level of serum AFP elevation
Children have better prognosis than adults

General Features.text: Ultrasonography may detect scrotal mass
Nonencapsulated, gray-white, soft or firm, homogeneous mass with myxoid or gelatinous cut surface
Tumors in adults are typically heterogeneous with other germ cell components and may have hemorrhage and necrosis

Cytologic Features.text: Relatively uniform epithelioid cells with clear or vacuolated to pale eosinophilic cytoplasm
Bland cuboidal, columnar to flattened, or frankly spindled cells with mild nuclear pleomorphism
Slight nuclear overlapping with indistinct cell borders; frequently deceptively benign looking

Histochemistry.text: Positive PAS with diastaseStaining pattern: Hyaline globules

Embryonal Carcinoma.text: Marked cytologic anaplasia, nuclear crowding, frequent mitoses and necrosis

Seminoma (Tubular).text: Usually accompanied by typical sheets or lobules of more uniform tumor cells separated by fibrous septa with lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate and granulomas

Rete Testis Hyperplasia ± Hyaline Globul.text: May occur in association ± germ cell tumor in testis

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Multiple different growth patterns
Microcystic and reticular patterns are common

Key Elements to Report.text: Pathologic stage
Presence of lymphovascular invasion
Involvement of rete testis, epididymis, spermatic cord, and tunica
Status of spermatic cord margin
Pathology of uninvolved testicular parenchyma

Terminology.text: Germ cell tumor composed of mixture of mononucleated trophoblastic cells and multinucleated syncytiotrophoblasts

Clinical Issues.text: Pure choriocarcinoma (CC) comprises < 1% of germ cell tumor
Known for early hematogeneous metastasis to lung, liver, and brain (cannonball metastasis)
Patients typically have very high circulating human chorionic gonadotropin (usually > 100,000 mIU/mL)

Macroscopic.text: Hemorrhagic and necrotic mass with blood clot; ill-defined gray to tan tissue at periphery

Microscopic.text: Classic CC consists of mixture of cytotrophoblasts and multinucleated syncytiotrophoblasts
Syncytiotrophoblasts wrapping around mononuclear cytotrophoblastic cells and forming villous configuration
Significant hemorrhage and necrosis
Monophasic CC, a variant of CC, is usually seen in metastatic sites following chemotherapy
Nonchoriocarcinomatous trophoblastic tumors (PSTT, ETT, and CTT) occurring in testis or metastatic sites have been reported

Ancillary Tests.text: Syncytiotrophoblasts are positive for cytokeratin, hCG, HPL, EMA/MUC1, inhibin, glypican-3, CEA, and SALL4
Cytotrophoblasts are (+) for SALL4, GDF3, p63, and GATA3
Negative for vimentin, CD30 (Ber-H2), podoplanin (D2-40), and OCT3/4

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Hemorrhage due to nonneoplastic process; other germ cell tumor with syncytiotrophoblasts, particularly seminoma; metastatic high-grade carcinoma

Abbreviations.text: Placental site trophoblastic tumor (PSTT), epithelioid trophoblastic tumor (ETT), cystic trophoblastic tumor (CTT)

Definitions.text: Germ cell tumor composed of admixture of mononucleated cytotrophoblastic and multinucleated syncytiotrophoblastic cells
Monophasic CC (rare, lacks syncytiotrophoblasts)
PSTT (extremely rare; tumor of intermediate trophoblasts)

Incidence.text: Pure CC accounts only for 0.3% of germ cell tumors
Usually mixed with other germ cell tumor components (8% of mixed germ cell tumors)

Presentation.text: Testicular mass less often than other germ cell tumors

Often presents with symptoms due to hematogeneous metastasis (hemoptysis, central nervous system dysfunction, hematemesis, melena, hypotension, anemia)May present with metastasis with subsequent detection of primary
sub_points: May present with metastasis with subsequent detection of primary

Presentation.text: May have gynecomastia (10% patients) or hyperthyroidism
Some patients may present with so-called CC syndrome due to multiorgan involvement and high human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) levels

Laboratory Tests.text: Patients with CC typically have very high circulating hCG (usually > 100,000 mIU/mL)
Patients with PSTT, ETT, and CTT may have elevation of hCG, but not as high as patients with CC

Treatment.text: Radical orchiectomy and systemic chemotherapy

Prognosis.text: Worse prognosis than other germ cell tumors, if pure
Level of hCG correlates with prognosis, reflecting tumor burden
Prognoses for PSTT, ETT, and CTT are likely not unfavorable, although data are relatively limited

General Features.text: Similar to other nonseminomatous germ cell tumors, but mass is usually small or inapparent in pure CC

Large multinucleate giant cells surrounding cytotrophoblasts with villous configuration

General Reporting Elements.text: Type of CC and cell types and their percentage

Terminology.text: Tumors with somatic tissue of > 1 different germinal layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, or endoderm)

Clinical Issues.text: Painless, firm, testicular mass
Pure form is rare and constitutes 4-9% of all testicular tumors in adults
Frequently mixed with other germ cell tumor types (more than 90%)
Adult teratomas are considered malignant because of relatively high recurrence or metastasis (22-37%)

Macroscopic.text: Often well-circumscribed, nodular and firm mass with heterogeneous cut surface with solid and cystic areas

Microscopic.text: Mature teratoma is composed of mixture of elements of ectoderm, endoderm, and mesoderm
Most common components are different types of epithelia, cartilage, or nerve
Respiratory and gastrointestinal epithelium, muscle, and cartilage are more commonly seen in testis than in ovary
Frequent germ cell neoplasia in situ in adjacent uninvolved testicular parenchyma
Immature teratoma is composed of undifferentiated spindle cells, primitive endoderm and primitive neuroectoderm tissue, blastomatous or embryonic rhabdomyoblastic tissue
Highly variable and depends on tissue type and maturity

Definitions.text: Tumors with somatic tissue of > 1 different germinal layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, or endoderm)

Genetics.text: Unlike prepubertal teratoma, adult teratomas are often aneuploid (hypotriploid) and associated with i (12p) and germ cell neoplasia in situ (GCNIS)

Incidence.text: Pure form is rare and constitutes 4-9% of all testicular tumors in adults
Frequently mixed with other germ cell tumor types (> 90%)

Age.text: Similar to that of mixed germ cell tumor (3rd-4th decades)

Presentation.text: Painless, firm, testicular mass

Treatment.text: For teratoma in adults, regardless of maturation, radical orchiectomy with close follow-up

Prognosis.text: Adult teratomas are considered malignant because of relatively high recurrence or metastasis (22-37%)

General Features.text: Solid and cystic testicular mass by US
Often well-circumscribed, nodular, and firm mass with heterogeneous cut surface with solid and cystic areas
Cysts filled with clear, white, flaky, gelatinous or mucoid material
Mature tissue with hair, cartilage, bone, or teeth may be seen

Cytologic Features.text: Highly variable and depends on tissue type and maturity

Immunohistochemistry.text: Highly variable and depends on component of teratoma (rarely necessary in clinical practice)Cytokeratin, CEA, and EMA/MUC1: Positive in epithelial tissue or carcinoma of teratomatous typeVimentin: Positive in mesenchymal tissueGerm cell markers: May be positive for HCG (syncytiotrophoblastic cells) and α-fetoprotein (enteric and hepatoid tissue); negative for PLAP (some glandular tissue); OCT3/4, SOX2, CD30
