Vimentin: Positive in mesenchymal tissue
Germ cell markers: May be positive for HCG (syncytiotrophoblastic cells) and α-fetoprotein (enteric and hepatoid tissue); negative for PLAP (some glandular tissue); OCT3/4, SOX2, CD30

Primary or Metastatic Sarcoma.text: More homogeneous population of pleomorphic spindle cells

Metastatic Carcinoma.text: Older age and clinical history of carcinoma elsewhere

Dermoid and Epidermoid Cysts.text: Cyst with organoid arrangement of stratified squamous epithelium with or without skin adnexal structures

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Multiple mature &/or immature tissue components of > 1 germ layer

Terminology.text: Germ cell tumor composed of > 1 histologic type of germ cell tumor, including seminoma

Clinical Issues.text: Range: 20-40 years (10 years younger than seminoma)
Accounts for 30-40% of all testicular germ cell tumors
Prognosis depends on clinical stage, proportion of embryonal carcinoma component, and lymphovascular invasion

Macroscopic.text: Variegated cystic and solid mass with hemorrhage and necrosis
Teratomatous components with bone, cartilage, and skin elements

Microscopic.text: Variable combination and percentage of any 2 or more germ cell tumor components
Most common combinations include embryonal carcinoma (EC) with yolk sac tumor (YST), teratoma (T), seminoma
Areas of necrosis and hemorrhage are common
Rare special variants include polyembryoma and diffuse embryoma

Ancillary Tests.text: Immunoprofile reflects histologic component of different germ cell tumors
1st-line germ cell markers: OCT3/4, PLAP, podoplanin (D2-40), CD30 (BerH2), glypican-3, HCG, cytokeratin
Other useful germ cell markers: CD117, AFP, SALL4, LIN28, NANOG

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Pure germ cell tumor, such as EC, YST, or teratoma

Definitions.text: Germ cell tumor composed of > 1 histologic type of germ cell tumor, including seminoma

Incidence.text: Most common nonseminomatous germ cell tumor (NSGCT) (30-40%)

Age.text: Range: 20-40 years (10 years younger than seminoma)
Rarely seen in prepubertal children and older adults (> 50 years)

Presentation.text: Testicular mass or swelling ± pain

Treatment.text: Similar to pure nonseminomatous germ cell tumor and depends on clinical stage
Radical inguinal orchiectomy ± retroperitoneal lymph node dissection or adjuvant therapy

Prognosis.text: Depends on clinical stage, proportion of embryonal carcinoma (unfavorable) and mature teratoma (favorable) component, rete testis interstitial invasion, and lymphovascular invasion
Cure rate > 95% for stage I and stage II disease, 70-85% for stage III disease

Radiographic Findings.text: Heterogeneous testicular mass on ultrasound examination
May be accompanied by retroperitoneal lymph node enlargement

General Features.text: Variegated cystic and solid mass with hemorrhage and necrosis
Teratomatous components with bone, cartilage, and skin elements

Sections to Be Submitted.text: Multiple sections of different areas of tumor and at least 1 section per cm tumor
Should include necrotic and hemorrhagic areas
Very important exercise to review gross

Histologic Features.text: Variable combination and percentage of any 2 or more germ cell tumor components
Most common combinations include embryonal carcinoma (EC) with yolk sac tumor (YST), teratoma (T), seminoma
Areas of necrosis and hemorrhage are common

Rare variants include polyembryoma and diffuse embryomaPolyembryoma is composed of entirely or predominantly embryoid bodies with embryonic disc, yolk sac, and surrounded by myxoid stromaDiffuse embryoma is characterized by intimate admixture of EC and YST with YST wrapping around EC component
sub_points: Polyembryoma is composed of entirely or predominantly embryoid bodies with embryonic disc, yolk sac, and surrounded by myxoid stroma
Diffuse embryoma is characterized by intimate admixture of EC and YST with YST wrapping around EC component

Cytologic Features.text: Reflects histologic composition of each component

Immunohistochemistry.text: Immunoprofile reflects histologic component of different germ cell tumors
1st-line germ cell markers: OCT3/4, PLAP, podoplanin (D2-40), CD30 (BerH2), glypican-3, hCG, cytokeratin
Other useful germ cell markers: CD117, AFP, SALL4, LIN28, NANOG

Pure Germ Cell Tumor.text: Single tumor component such as embryonal carcinoma, yolk sac tumor, or teratoma

Metastatic Carcinoma.text: Interstitial pattern is frequently seen in metastatic carcinoma

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Mixture of different histologic components of germ cell neoplasm

Key Elements to Report.text: Specific histologic types and percentage of each component
Lymphovascular invasion
Invasion of rete testis, epididymis, spermatic cord, and tunica
Pathology of uninvolved testicular parenchyma

Terminology.text: Specialized benign form of testicular cyst with keratinizing squamous lining without skin adnexal structures (epidermoid cyst)
Specialized benign form of monodermal cystic teratoma with keratinizing squamous lining and skin adnexal structures (dermoid cyst)

Clinical Issues.text: < 1% of testicular tumors
Dermoid cyst more rare than epidermoid cyst
Painless testicular enlargement over several years
Cured by surgical resection

Macroscopic Features.text: Unilocular intraparenchymal cystic lesion containing keratin debris

Microscopic Features.text: Epidermoid cyst: Unilocular cyst with keratinized squamous epithelial lining containing granular cell layer, no skin adnexal structures
Dermoid cyst: Usually unilocular cyst lined by epidermis and dermis containing skin adnexal structures (hair follicle, sebaceous, apocrine or eccrine glands)
Other noncutaneous elements (such as ciliated epithelium, small bowel mucosa and submucosa) may be seen but maintain organoid arrangement
Lipogranulomatous reaction to cyst contents may be seen
Uninvolved testis has normal spermatogenesis with no significant atrophy or "dysgenetic features"

Definitions.text: Specialized benign form of testicular cyst with keratinizing squamous lining without skin adnexal structures (epidermoid cyst)
Specialized benign form of monodermal cystic teratoma with keratinizing squamous lining and skin adnexal structures (dermoid cyst)

Pathogenesis.text: Pathogenesis of epidermoid cyst is still controversialSome consider it as nonteratogenic, either from epithelial inclusion or from metaplastic mesotheliumOthers suggest that it is teratomatous because of loss of heterozygosity for certain chromosomal loci
sub_points: Some consider it as nonteratogenic, either from epithelial inclusion or from metaplastic mesothelium
Others suggest that it is teratomatous because of loss of heterozygosity for certain chromosomal loci

Pathogenesis.text: Dermoid cyst is considered a specialized form of teratomaDifferent from mature teratoma; believed to be derived from nontransformed germ cells and is unrelated to intratubular germ cell neoplasia (ITGCN)
sub_points: Different from mature teratoma; believed to be derived from nontransformed germ cells and is unrelated to intratubular germ cell neoplasia (ITGCN)

Incidence.text: < 1% of testicular tumors
Dermoid cyst more rare than epidermoid cyst

Presentation.text: Painless or painful palpable testicular enlargement over several years
May be incidental finding

Laboratory Tests.text: Serum tumor markers (LDH, AFP, and hCG) are not elevated

Surgical approaches.text: Cured by resection
May be amenable to partial orchiectomy

Prognosis.text: Benign behavior

General Features.text: Intratesticular hypoechoic cystic mass with "onion ring" appearance on ultrasound due to laminated keratin
Intraparenchymal, well-defined fibrous-walled cystic lesion containing degenerating keratin debris ± adnexal structures (dermoid vs. epidermoid cyst)

Histologic Features.text: Epidermoid cystUsually unilocular cyst with keratinized squamous epithelial lining containing a granular cell layer without skin adnexal structuresCystic wall may be calcified or ossified
sub_points: Usually unilocular cyst with keratinized squamous epithelial lining containing a granular cell layer without skin adnexal structures
Cystic wall may be calcified or ossified

Histologic Features.text: Dermoid cystUsually unilocular cyst filled with keratin debris or hairLined by epidermis and dermis containing skin adnexal structures (hair follicle, sebaceous, apocrine or eccrine glands)Orderly arrangement of pilosebaceous units to epidermal surface resembling that of skinOther noncutaneous elements (such as ciliated epithelium, small bowel mucosa and submucosa) may be seen, but maintain organoid arrangementCystic wall with smooth muscle bundles may be present; cartilage, fibrous tissue, and neuroglia have rarely been reportedLipogranulomatous reaction to cyst contents may be seen"Pilomatrixoma" as variant of dermoid cyst has been reportedUninvolved testis has normal spermatogenesis with no significant atrophy or "dysgenetic features"
sub_points: Usually unilocular cyst filled with keratin debris or hair
Lined by epidermis and dermis containing skin adnexal structures (hair follicle, sebaceous, apocrine or eccrine glands)
Orderly arrangement of pilosebaceous units to epidermal surface resembling that of skin
Other noncutaneous elements (such as ciliated epithelium, small bowel mucosa and submucosa) may be seen, but maintain organoid arrangement
Cystic wall with smooth muscle bundles may be present; cartilage, fibrous tissue, and neuroglia have rarely been reported
Lipogranulomatous reaction to cyst contents may be seen
"Pilomatrixoma" as variant of dermoid cyst has been reported
Uninvolved testis has normal spermatogenesis with no significant atrophy or "dysgenetic features"

Histologic Features.text: Lack of intratubular germ cell neoplasia (ITGCN)
No other somatic tissue or malignant germ cell elements

Cytologic Features.text: Mature keratinizing squamous epithelial cells (both dermoid and epidermoid) and skin adnexal structures (dermoid)

Immunohistochemistry.text: Cytokeratin may rarely be necessary to demonstrate squamous epithelium in ruptured or calcified/ossified lesion
Immunostain with germ cell markers (CD117, Oct3/4, Podoplanin[D2-40]) to rule out presence of ITGCN

Mature Cystic Teratoma.text: Presence of other teratomatous components and presence of ITGCN
Uninvolved testis shows pronounced widespread atrophy or "dysgenetic features"

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Benign, mature, squamous-lined cyst with granular cell layer and keratin material; without (epidermoid cyst) and with skin adnexal structures (dermoid cyst)

Terminology.text: Germ cell tumor composed of 3 cell types of variable sizes ranging 6-100 µm

Clinical Issues.text: Rare testis germ cell tumor (1-2%)
Average age of patients: 53.6 yr
Painless testicular swelling and mass
Serum tumor markers are not elevated
Radical inguinal orchiectomy alone is curative

Macroscopic.text: Well-circumscribed, soft, friable, tan-gray mass with mucoid or gelatinous, bulging cut surface

Microscopic.text: Diffuse or solid sheet-like pattern with scant fibrous or edematous stroma is most common finding
Rare growth patterns include pseudoglandular, microcystic, trabecular, nests, or single cells
Polymorphous cell population is hallmark of spermatocytic seminoma: Small lymphocyte-like cells, intermediate cells, and giant cells
Lack cytoplasmic glycogen, fibrovascular septa, lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate, or granulomatous inflammation
Lack association with germ cell neoplasia in situ

Ancillary Tests.text: Negative for most germ cell-associated markers [OCT3/OCT4, Podoplanin (D2-40), PLAP, α-fetoprotein, glypican-3, HCG, and CD30(BerH2)], cytokeratin, and vimentin
Positive for SALL4, CD117, MAGE-A4, OCT2, SSX, SAGE1; often focal or patchy

Definitions.text: Germ cell tumor recapitulating spermatogenic sequence composed of 3 cell types of variable sizes, ranging 6-100 µm

Cytogenetic Changes.text: Diploid or near hypodiploid, different from that of seminoma
Chromosomal numerical changes (most commonly gain of chromosome 9)
Group of heterogenous tumors that originate from different types of spermatogonia

Incidence.text: Rare testis germ cell tumor (< 1%); bilaterality is more common (> 9%) than in seminoma
No ovarian or extragonadal counterpart of spermatocytic seminoma
Not associated with cryptorchidism; no race predilection as in other germ cell tumors

Presentation.text: Painless testicular swelling and mass
Serum tumor markers are not elevated

Treatment.text: Radical inguinal orchiectomy alone is curative

Prognosis.text: Excellent prognosis with rare malignant behavior (< 1%)
Sarcomatoid transformation is rare but when present is associated with distant metastasis and death

General Features.text: Well-circumscribed, soft, friable, tan-gray mass with mucoid or gelatinous, bulging cut surface
Lobulation, cystic change, focal hemorrhage or necrosis may be seen

Histologic Features.text: Diffuse or solid sheet-like pattern with scant fibrous or edematous stroma is most common finding
Other rarer patterns include pseudoglandular, microcystic, trabecular, nests, or single cells

Polymorphous cell population with 3 distinct cell types is hallmark of spermatocytic tumorSmall lymphocyte-like cells: 6-8 µm; densely hyperchromatic nuclei and scant amount of cytoplasmIntermediate cells: 15-20 µm; most common cell type; round nuclei, finely granular chromatin, variable nucleoli, moderate amount of cytoplasm; occasional spireme-type chromatinGiant cells: 50-100 µm; least common cell type; distinctive filamentous or spireme-type chromatin
sub_points: Small lymphocyte-like cells: 6-8 µm; densely hyperchromatic nuclei and scant amount of cytoplasm
Intermediate cells: 15-20 µm; most common cell type; round nuclei, finely granular chromatin, variable nucleoli, moderate amount of cytoplasm; occasional spireme-type chromatin
Giant cells: 50-100 µm; least common cell type; distinctive filamentous or spireme-type chromatin

Histologic Features.text: Lack cytoplasmic glycogen, fibrovascular septa, lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate, or granulomatous inflammation
Intratubular spermatocytic seminoma with large, highly atypical cells expanding tubules may be seen
Lack association with germ cell neoplasia in situ
Anaplastic spermatocytic seminoma is characterized by predominantly monomorphous intermediate-sized cells with prominent nucleoli and brisk mitoses
Sarcomatous transformation may rarely occur (6%) and is characterized by undifferentiated primitive spindle cell sarcoma; rhabdomyoblastic differentiation has been reported

Cytologic Features.text: 3 distinct cell types with small, intermediate, and giant cells

Immunohistochemistry.text: Positive for SALL4, CD117, MAGE-A4, OCT2, SSX, SAGE1
Negative for most germ cell-associated markers [OCT3/OCT4, Podoplanin (D2-40), PLAP, α-fetoprotein, glypican-3, HCG, and CD30(BerH2)], cytokeratin, and vimentin

Classic Seminoma.text: Relatively monotonous cell population with fibrovascular septa, lymphoplasmacytic and granulomatous inflammation

Embryonal Carcinoma (Solid Pattern).text: Greater extent of cytologic anaplasia with different concurrent growth patterns (solid, glandular, and papillary)
Positive for cytokeratin and OCT3/OCT4, CD30

Malignant Lymphoma.text: Typical interstitial growth pattern with uniform cell population
Positive for CD45 (LCA), and CD20 or CD3

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Polymorphous cell population with 3 distinct cell types, including small lymphocytic, intermediate, and large giant cells
Lack of fibrovascular septa and lymphoplasmacytic infiltrates or granulomas

Terminology.text: Pure testicular stromal tumor composed of cells that recapitulate normal interstitial (Leydig) cells

Clinical Issues.text: Most common type of sex cord-stromal tumor (1-3% of testicular neoplasms)
Majority have benign behavior; 5-10% malignant

Macroscopic.text: Well-circumscribed, intraparenchymal nodule with golden-brown to yellow, or gray-white homogeneous cut surface

Microscopic.text: Growth patterns: Diffuse (most common), lobular, insular, tubular, ribbon-like, and pseudofollicular
Large, round or polygonal cells with well-defined cell borders, eosinophilic or vacuolated cytoplasm
Relatively uniform round or ovoid nuclei, prominent nucleoli; focal nuclear pleomorphism, binucleated or multinucleated cells may be seen
Cytoplasmic vacuoles or foamy cytoplasm (lipid content), lipofuscin (15%), and Reinke crystals (30-40%) may be seen
Other uncommon features: Fatty metaplasia; spindle, clear cell, or microcystic changes; myxoid degeneration; calcification or ossification; and rhabdoid features
Metastasis is only criterion for malignancy

Ancillary Tests.text: Positive for inhibin-α, calretinin, Melan-A (MART-1), WT1, androgenic hormones (P450scc, 3β-HSD, etc.), CD99, steroidogenic factor (SF-1), and vimentin (strong and diffuse)

Negative for cytokeratin, chromogranin, and synaptophysin (rarely focally positive for these 3 markers), S100 and PLAP (rarely positive for these 2 markers), nuclear beta-catenin, germ cell tumor markers

Definitions.text: Pure testicular stromal tumor composed of cells that recapitulate normal interstitial (Leydig) cells

Incidence.text: Most common type of sex cord-stromal tumor (1-3% of testicular tumors)
Rarely associated with Klinefelter syndrome
Rare association with the hereditary leiomyomatosis renal cell carcinoma (HLRCC) syndrome caused by germline mutations of fumarate hydratase (FH) gene

Presentation.text: Testicular enlargement, usually painless, decreased libido (20%), gynecomastia (15%), undescended testis (10%), or precocious puberty
May produce testosterone, androstenedione, and dehydroepiandrosterone
May be associated with cryptorchidism, testicular atrophy, infertility
Bilaterality in 3% of cases

Surgical approaches.text: Orchiectomy is curative in majority of tumors; baseline staging work-up is required
Retroperitoneal lymph node dissection may be required in older patients and those with tumors with unfavorable histology
Testis-sparing surgery possible for young men

Prognosis.text: Majority have benign behavior
~ 5-10% are malignant and may metastasize

General Features.text: Well-circumscribed, intraparenchymal mass with golden-brown to yellow, or gray-white homogeneous cut surface, lobulation may be seen
Focal hemorrhage or necrosis may be seen (25%)
Most confined within testis; extratesticular extension possible (10%)

Histologic Features.text: Growth patterns: Diffuse (most common), lobular, insular, tubular, ribbon-like, and pseudofollicular
Large, round or polygonal cells with well-defined cell borders, eosinophilic or vacuolated cytoplasm
Relatively uniform round or ovoid nuclei, prominent nucleoli; focal nuclear pleomorphism (including endocrine-type), binucleated, or multinucleated cells may be seen
Cytoplasmic vacuoles or foamy cytoplasm (lipid content), lipofuscin (15%), and Reinke crystals (30-40%) may be seen
Frequent fibrous, hyalinized, edematous or myxoid stroma
Other uncommon features: Fatty metaplasia; spindle, clear cell, or microcystic changes; myxoid degeneration; calcification or ossification; and rhabdoid features
Features that tend to be seen more often in malignant tumors: Large tumor size (> 5 cm), infiltrative borders, vascular invasion, nuclear atypia, necrosis, high mitotic rate (> 3/10 HPF)
Metastasis is only criterion for malignancy

Cytologic Features.text: Large, round or polygonal cells with prominent nucleoli, abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, and well-defined cell borders

Immunohistochemistry.text: Positive for inhibin-α, calretinin, Melan-A (MART-1), WT1, androgenic hormones (P450scc, 3β-HSD, etc.), CD99, steroidogenic factor (SF-1), and vimentin (strong and diffuse)

Negative for cytokeratin, chromogranin, and synaptophysin (rarely focally positive for these 3 markers), S100 and PLAP (rarely positive for these 2 markers), nuclear beta-catenin, germ cell tumor markers

Genetic Testing.text: Most frequent changes including gains of chromosomes X, 19, and 19p and losses of chromosomes 8 and 16

Malignant Lymphoma.text: Older age, frequent bilaterality, interstitial growth, malignant cytologic features, onion skin appearance of seminiferous tubule involvement
Positive for CD45 (LCA), and usually B-cell marker positive; negative for inhibin-α, calretinin, Melan-A (MART-1)

Large Cell Calcifying Sertoli Cell Tumor.text: More calcification, frequent bilaterality (40%), intratubular growth of tumor cells, nests or cords of growth

Testicular Tumors of Adrenogenital Syndr.text: Multinodular, bilaterality, pleomorphism, pigmentation, and hyalinized fibrous stroma, interstitial growth pattern with entrapped seminiferous tubules

Ectopic Leydig Cells Mimicking Extratest.text: Cytologically bland Leydig cell proliferation in extratesticular locations (tunica albuginea, epididymis, spermatic cord)

Leydig Cell Hyperplasia.text: Small size (< 0.5 cm), multifocal, shows interstitial growth with intervening seminiferous tubules

Other Lesions with Eosinophilic Cytoplas.text: Malakoplakia, hepatoid yolk sac tumor, carcinoid tumor, and metastatic malignant melanoma

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Well-defined solid tumoral growth of relatively bland-looking uniform cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm
Metastasis is only criterion for malignancy

Terminology.text: Pure sex cord-stromal tumor composed of Sertoli cells

Clinical Issues.text: < 1% of testicular tumors; most are sporadic
All ages (average: 45 yr)
Slowly enlarging testicular mass

Macroscopic.text: Small, well-circumscribed, homogeneous gray-white to yellow, firm mass

Microscopic.text: Growth patterns: Tubules, microcystic, solid cords and nests, and rarely spindled (sarcomatoid)
Most common pattern is tubule formation surrounded by basement membrane
Uniform cuboidal or columnar cells with moderate pale to lightly eosinophilic cytoplasm, often prominent cytoplasmic vacuoles
Bland round to ovoid nuclei, occasional centrally located nucleoli, and rare mitoses
May have paucicellular, hyalinized, vascular fibrous stroma, or lymphoid aggregates
Charcot-Böttcher filaments (perinuclear arrays of filaments) are considered pathognomonic of Sertoli cell differentiation by electron microscopy

Ancillary Tests.text: Positive for CK-PAN (AE1/AE3), EMA/MUC1, vimentin, α-inhibin, Melan-A (MART-1), WT1, SF1, CD99, calretinin, S100 (weak), SOX9, nuclear β-catenin (60-70%): synaptophysin may be positive
Negative for PLAP, Podoplanin (D2-40), OCT3/OCT4, SALL4, α-fetoprotein, CD30 (BerH2), HCG

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Yolk sac tumor or seminoma (tubular) or malignant

Definitions.text: Pure sex cord-stromal tumor of Sertoli cell origin that shows variety of architectural patterns, including solid growth, but which shows at least focal tubular differentiation

Incidence.text: < 1% of testicular tumors; most are sporadic
May occur in patients with undescended testes, Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, Carney syndrome, androgen insensitivity, and testicular feminization syndromes

Age.text: Occurs in any age with no age predilection (average: 45 yr)
Up to 30% occur in 1st decade of life

Presentation.text: Asymptomatic, slowly enlarging testicular mass, most unilateral
Hormone-related symptoms are unusual; may present with hyperestrinism (gynecomastia)

Surgical approaches.text: Surgical resection is often curative (radiation and chemotherapy have little effect)

Prognosis.text: Up to 10% may be malignant
Excellent prognosis unless metastasis occurs, usually involves retroperitoneal lymph nodes but may also be in hematogenous distribution

General Features.text: Usually small, well-circumscribed, homogeneous gray-white to yellow, firm mass
May be lobulated with focal cystic changes or hemorrhage

Histologic Features.text: Growth patterns: Tubules, microcystic, cords, nests, solid sheets, and rarely spindled (sarcomatoid)Most common pattern is tubules, which are hollow, round, solid, or elongated
sub_points: Most common pattern is tubules, which are hollow, round, solid, or elongated

Histologic Features.text: Uniform cuboidal or columnar cells with moderate pale to lightly eosinophilic cytoplasm, often with prominent cytoplasmic vacuoles
Bland, round to ovoid nuclei, occasionally centrally located nucleoli, and rare mitoses
May have paucicellular, hyalinized, or vascular fibrous stroma; lymphoid aggregates may be present
May have clear cells arranged in nests by fibrous septa and lymphoid infiltrates resembling that of seminoma
Entrapped germ cells within Sertoli cell tumor (usually at periphery) may mimic mixed germ cell sex cord-stromal tumor
Some tumors may have abundant cytoplasmic lipid (lipid-rich variant)

Features seen more often in tumors with malignant outcome includeLarge size (> 5 cm), lymphovascular invasion, and extratesticular extensionMarked nuclear pleomorphism, increased mitoses (> 5/10 high power fields), and necrosis
sub_points: Large size (> 5 cm), lymphovascular invasion, and extratesticular extension
Marked nuclear pleomorphism, increased mitoses (> 5/10 high power fields), and necrosis

Histologic Features.text: Sclerosing Sertoli cell tumorCharacterized by markedly sclerotic fibrous stroma (comprising at least 50% of the tumor) containing cords, solid or hollow tubules, and nests of Sertoli cells
sub_points: Characterized by markedly sclerotic fibrous stroma (comprising at least 50% of the tumor) containing cords, solid or hollow tubules, and nests of Sertoli cells

Cytologic Features.text: Cuboidal to columnar cells, pale-to-eosinophilic cytoplasm, round-to-ovoid nuclei, and variably centrally located nucleoli

Predominant Pattern/Injury Type.text: Tubular-glandular pattern or solid sheets, rarely spindle cell sarcomatoid pattern

Predominant Cell/Compartment Type.text: Uniform, bland, oval-to-round cells or may have spindle cells

Immunohistochemistry.text: Positive for CK-PAN (AE1/AE3), EMA/MUC1, vimentin, α-inhibin, Melan-A (MART-1), WT1, SF1, CD99, calretinin, S100 (weak), SOX9, nuclear β-catenin (60-70%): Synaptophysin may be positive
Negative for PLAP, Podoplanin (D2-40), OCT3/OCT4, SALL4, α-fetoprotein, CD30 (BerH2), HCG

Genetic Testing.text: Gain of chromosome X (~ 40%) and rarely deletion of entire or part of chromosomes 2 and 19
CTNNB1gene (encodes β-catenin) mutations in some tumors

Electron Microscopy.text: Charcot-Böttcher filaments (perinuclear arrays of filaments) are pathognomonic of Sertoli cell differentiation

Yolk Sac Tumor or Seminoma (Tubular).text: Yolk sac tumor (microcystic or glandular) and seminoma (tubular) have larger tumor cells, prominent nucleoli, and abundant cytoplasm
Positive for germ cell markers; negative for inhibin and calretinin
Malignant Sertoli cell tumors may have fibrous septa but no germ cell neoplasia in situ

Leydig Cell Tumor.text: Usually solid growth with large cells containing abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm
Yellow-to-brown gross appearance, lack of tubular differentiation, and negative for cytokeratin

Adenomatoid Tumor.text: Location usually in paratesticular site or epididymis

Rete Testis Carcinoma or Metastatic Carc.text: Greater cytologic anaplasia and desmoplastic stroma
Dysplastic rete testis epithelium or history of extratesticular carcinoma

Sertoli Cell Nodule.text: Tubules with thickened basement membranes and hyaline bodies lined by immature Sertoli cells

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Tubular pattern, range of cytologic features and cytoplasmic characteristics, cytokeratin and inhibin positive

Large Cell Calcifying Sertoli Cell Tumor.name: Large Cell Calcifying Sertoli Cell Tumor

Terminology.text: Variant of Sertoli cell tumor with large epithelioid cells and peculiar calcifications, often associated with clinical syndromes

Clinical Issues.text: Extremely rare; only ~ 50 cases have been reported
Range: 1.5-48 years (average: 16 years)
Sporadic (60%) or as component of Carney and Peutz-Jeghers syndromes

Macroscopic.text: Well-circumscribed, white-tan or yellow mass associated with granular or gritty calcifications
Usually < 4 cm

Microscopic.text: Common growth patterns include nests, cords or trabeculae, or solid tubules
Large polygonal cells with abundant eosinophilic, ground-glass, or finely granular cytoplasm
Tumor cells have vesicular nuclei and prominent nucleoli
Fibrous or myxohyaline stroma with marked calcifications
May have marked neutrophilic infiltration
Some have intratubular growth

Ancillary Tests.text: Positive for Melan-A (MART-1), inhibin-α, S100, desmin, actin-sm, SF-1
Negative for nuclear beta-catenin, cytokeratin (may be focally positive), α-fetoprotein, HCG, PLAP, podoplanin (D2-40), and OCT3/4

Abbreviations.text: Large cell calcifying Sertoli cell tumor (LCCSCT)

Definitions.text: Variant of Sertoli cell tumor with large epithelioid cells and peculiar calcifications, often associated with clinical syndromes

Incidence.text: Extremely rare

Presentation.text: Slowly enlarging, painless testicular mass
Sporadic (60%) or as component of Carney and Peutz-Jeghers syndromes
May be associated with adrenocortical hyperplasia, hypercortisolemia, or testicular Leydig cell tumor
Bilaterality (40%) and multifocality (60%), associated with Carney syndrome; unilateral and unifocal in sporadic cases
Tumors occurring in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome are distinctive and called intratubular large cell hyalinizing Sertoli cell neoplasia
Malignant form reported: Mean age: 39 years; more often unilateral and solitary compared to benign tumors

Surgical approaches.text: Orchiectomy is usually curative; long-term follow-up is necessary

Prognosis.text: Excellent, but some (20%) may have malignant behavior

Radiographic Findings.text: Ultrasound may detect testicular mass with brightly echogenic area (due to calcifications)

General Features.text: Well-circumscribed, white-tan or yellow mass associated with granular or gritty calcifications

Size.text: Usually < 4 cm; malignant tumor may be larger

Histologic Features.text: Common growth patterns include nests, cords, trabeculae, or solid tubules
Large polygonal cells with abundant eosinophilic, ground-glass, or finely granular cytoplasm
Tumor cells have vesicular nuclei and prominent nucleoli
Calcifications are a hallmark; large, wavy laminated nodules, sometimes small psammoma bodies and rare ossification
Fibrous or myxohyaline stroma
May have marked neutrophilic infiltration

sub_points: Distinct morphologic variant of LCCSCT

Negative for nuclear beta-catenin, cytokeratin (may be focally positive), α-fetoprotein, HCG, PLAP, podoplanin (D2-40), and OCT3/4

Leydig Cell Tumor.text: Usually lacks calcification and has a more solid growth pattern, although it may be rarely ossified
No intratubular growth and bilaterally is less common
Usually sporadic with no syndromic association

Tumor of Adrenogenital Syndrome.text: Solid growth pattern is more frequent with no intratubular component

Sertoli Cell Tumor.text: Large epithelioid cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm are distinctly uncommon
Calcification or neutrophilic infiltration is absent; uncommonly bilateral

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Large cells, calcifications, nests and cords formation, neutrophilic stromal infiltrate

Terminology.text: Adult testicular tumor of granulosa cell differentiation resembling ovarian counterpart

Clinical Issues.text: Extremely rare in the testis; accounting for < 0.5% of all sex cord-stromal tumors
Range: 16-76 years (average: 44 years)

Macroscopic.text: Well-circumscribed, sometimes encapsulated, homogeneous, yellow to gray, firm mass

Microscopic.text: Growth patterns: Diffuse (most common), microfollicular, trabecular, insular, macrofollicular, gyriform, or cystic
Presence of Call-Exner bodies (eosinophilic material surrounded by palisading granulosa cells)
Relatively uniform round or ovoid cells (carrot-shaped) with scant, lightly staining cytoplasm
Elongated or angular nuclei with grooves (coffee bean-shaped) and 1 or 2 peripherally located nucleoli
Some show focal theca cell differentiation or have smooth muscle or osteoid differentiation
Features seen more often in malignant tumors: Large size (> 7 cm), mitoses, necrosis, lymphovascular invasion

Ancillary Tests.text: Positive for vimentin, inhibin, calretinin, SMA, CD56, FOXL2, SF1, S100, and focally positive for CK-PAN (AE1/AE3)
Negative for EMA, nuclear beta-catenin, PLAP, podoplanin (D2-40), OCT3/4, SALL4, AFP, HCG, CD30 (BerH2)

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Mixed germ cell and sex cord-stromal tumor (gonadoblastoma or unclassified)

Definitions.text: Sex cord-stromal tumor of testis occurring in adults and resembling its counterpart of ovarian granulosa cell tumor

Incidence.text: Extremely rare; accounting for < 0.5% of all sex cord-stromal tumors

Age.text: Juvenile GCT occurs in 1st few months of life

Presentation.text: Painless testicular mass
May be associated with gynecomastia (~ 25%)

Surgical approaches.text: Curable by surgical resection in most cases
May be managed by partial orchiectomy

Prognosis.text: Most have indolent clinical course but have malignant potential
Metastasis has been reported (20% of cases), most frequently to retroperitoneal lymph nodes but may metastasize to liver, lungs, and bone
Long-term follow-up is recommended for all patients

General Features.text: Well-circumscribed, sometimes encapsulated, homogeneous, yellow to gray, firm, lobulated mass
Cysts may be seen infrequently
Hemorrhage or necrosis is unusual

Histologic Features.text: Growth patterns: Diffuse (most common), microfollicular, trabecular, insular, macrofollicular, gyriform, or cystic
Presence of Call-Exner bodies (eosinophilic material surrounded by palisading granulosa cells)
Relatively uniform round or ovoid cells (carrot-shaped) with scant, lightly staining cytoplasm
Elongated or angular nuclei with grooves (coffee bean-shaped) and 1 or 2 peripherally located nucleoli
Focal cytologic atypia and rare mitoses; mitoses may be high with varying degree of nuclear pleomorphism
May intermingle with seminiferous tubules and infiltrate tunica albuginea
Some show focal theca cell differentiation or have smooth muscle or osteoid differentiation
Rare hemorrhage, necrosis, or angiolymphatic invasion
Features seen more often in tumors with malignant outcome: Large size (> 7 cm), frequent mitoses (> 4/10 HPF), hemorrhage, necrosis, lymphovascular invasion

Terminology.text: Testicular tumor that is multicystic and composed of multiple follicles lined by granulosa and theca-like cells

Infants younger than 2 years old; most common testis tumor in infants < 6 months

Macroscopic.text: Well-circumscribed or partially encapsulated multicystic mass with solid yellow and variable papillary areas

Microscopic.text: Multiple irregular cystic areas interspersed with solid areas
Variably sized follicles lined by bland-looking oval round cells arranged in single or multiple layers with outer layers resembling theca cells
Granulosa cells have round to ovoid nuclei, inconspicuous nucleoli, and scant to vacuolated cytoplasm
Mitotic activity is usually evident and often prominent

Call-Exner bodies and nuclear grooves, often seen in adult granulosa cell tumor are absent

Negative for EMA/MUC1, α-fetoprotein, PLAP, podoplanin (D2-40), OCT3/4, SALL4, glypican-3, CD45 (LCA)

Most common testicular tumor in infants
6.6% of all prepubertal testicular tumors

Prognosis.text: Clinically benign

Well-circumscribed or partially encapsulated multicystic mass with solid yellow and papillary areas

Terminology.text: Tumor composed of mixture of seminomatous cells and immature sex cord tumor resembling Sertoli or granulosa cell tumors

Terminology.text: Lymphoma and plasmacytoma of testis or paratesticular structures, which is either primary or secondary due to systemic spread
Secondary leukemic infiltrates

Clinical Issues.text: Malignant lymphoma accounts for 2-5% of all testicular neoplasms

Fleshy, creamy colored, tan, pale yellow or slightly pink homogeneous cut surface

Other lymphomas include MALT lymphomas, follicular lymphomas, extranodal NK/T-cell lymphomas, anaplastic large cell lymphoma, Burkitt lymphoma, and plasmablastic lymphoma

Terminology.text: Benign paratesticular tumor of mesothelial cell origin, which has variety of growth patterns, including glands, cysts, tubules, cords, or isolated cells

Clinical Issues.text: Most common tumor of testicular adnexa (32%)

Definitions.text: Benign paratesticular tumor of mesothelial cell origin, which has variety of growth patterns, including glands, cysts, tubules, cords, or isolated cells

Incidence.text: Most common tumor of testicular adnexa

Presentation.text: Usually asymptomatic, small and solid intrascrotal mass
Most commonly occurs in head of epididymis, although may occur in tunica vaginalis, albuginea, and rete testis
Tumors may rarely be intratesticular and involve parietal tunica or spermatic cord

Surgical approaches.text: Surgical excision is curative

Prognosis.text: Benign clinical course

General Features.text: Small, well-circumscribed, white-tan, homogeneous, firm mass
No hemorrhage or necrosis

Histologic Features.text: Well-circumscribed, unencapsulated mass
Tubules; gland-like, irregular cystic spaces or channels
Nests and cords; pure solid pattern rare
Cuboidal, flat, or ovoid cells with round nuclei and abundant dense cytoplasm with vacuoles
May show signet ring cell appearance
May have prominent smooth muscle (leiomyomatous adenomatoid tumor)
May be cellular or infarcted
Lymphoid aggregates may be prominent within or at periphery of tumor
Rare tumors may be infarcted

Cytologic Features.text: Cuboidal, flat or ovoid, eosinophilic, vacuolated, signet ring

Predominant Pattern/Injury Type.text: Nests, cords, gland-like, tubular, cystic, and plexiform

Predominant Cell/Compartment Type.text: Cuboidal to flat to ovoid with uniform cytology

Immunohistochemistry.text: Positive for cytokeratin, calretinin, podoplanin (D2-40), CK5/6, thrombomodulin, WT1
Negative for CEA, CD15, MOC-31, EpCAM/BER-EP4/CD326, S100, CD31, CD34, FLI-1

Malignant Mesothelioma.text: Larger tumor, destructive and infiltrative growth

Metastatic Signet Ring Cell Carcinoma.text: Infiltrative growth, greater cytologic atypia, frequent mitoses
Positive for CEA, CD15, EpCAM/BER-EP4/CD326, and MOC-31; negative for calretinin and podoplanin (D2-40)

Epithelioid Hemangioma/Hemangioendotheli.text: Vasoformative lesion composed of vacuolated cells
Positive for vascular markers (CD31, CD34, FLI-1); negative or weakly/focally positive for cytokeratin

Germ Cell Tumors (Particularly Yolk Sac.text: Positive for OCT3/4, SALL4, and CD30 (BerH2); negative for calretinin

Leiomyosarcoma or Leiomyoma (vs. Leiomyo.text: More compact cellular spindle cell proliferation with cytologic atypia and increased mitoses in leiomyosarcoma
Lack of tubules or cystic spaces
Negative or focally positive for cytokeratin

Liposarcoma.text: Presence of lipoblasts and variable cells with adipocytic quality

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Adenomatoid tumor may show a variety of patterns mimicking signet ring cell carcinoma, vascular tumor, and sex cord-stromal tumor
Paratesticular location and excellent circumscription are key in distinction of histologic differential diagnosis from malignant tumors

Terminology.text: Malignant tumor originating from mesothelial cells of tunica vaginalis

Clinical Issues.text: Rare, but 2nd most common paratesticular malignancy after soft tissue sarcoma
< 50% reported cases associated with asbestos exposure
Age range: 6-90 yr (average: 54 yr)
Paratesticular mass or associated with hydrocele

Microscopic.text: Majority pure epithelial (60-70%) or biphasic type (30-40%)
Common growth patterns: Papillary, tubulopapillary, glandular (well differentiated), or solid growth patterns (poorly differentiated)
Rare sarcomatoid or desmoplastic types occur as well
Round or cuboidal cells with mild or moderate cellular pleomorphism and often prominent nucleoli
Dense hyperchromatic chromatin and frequent mitoses
Foam cells, psammoma bodies may be seen
Invasion is key diagnostic criterion

Ancillary Tests.text: Positive for CK-PAN (AE1/AE3), EMA/MUC1, vimentin, calretinin, podoplanin (D2-40), CK5/CK6, thrombomodulin, mesothelin, and WT1
Negative for CEA, TAG72, CD15, EPCAM/BER-EP4/CD326

Definitions.text: Malignant tumor arising from mesothelial cells in tunica vaginalis

Pathogenesis.text: Asbestos exposure is only known risk factor (associated with < 50% of cases in testicular mesothelioma)

Incidence.text: Rare, but 2nd most common paratesticular malignancy after soft tissue sarcoma

Age.text: 10% of cases occur in patients younger than 25 yr

Presentation.text: Paratesticular mass or associated with hydrocele

Surgical approaches.text: Surgical resection is treatment of choice
Adjuvant chemotherapy has been proved to have limited effect

Prognosis.text: Variable depending on clinical stage; usually poor

General Features.text: Variable, often diffuse thickening of tunica vaginalis with multiple friable nodules or excrescences
Tumor may invade tunica albuginea, testis, epididymis, and spermatic cord

Histologic Features.text: Majority pure epithelial (60-70%) or biphasic type (30-40%)
Common growth patterns: Papillary, tubulopapillary, glandular (well differentiated), or solid growth patterns (poorly differentiated)
Rare sarcomatoid or desmoplastic types may also occur
Round or cuboidal cells with mild or moderate cellular pleomorphism and often prominent nucleoli
Dense chromatin with variable mitotic activity
Foam cells or psammoma bodies may be present
Cytologic atypia or mesothelial proliferation alone may not be diagnostic for malignant mesothelioma
Invasion beyond tunica is key diagnostic criterion

Predominant Cell/Compartment Type.text: Cuboidal or oval round, relatively uniform cells with prominent nucleolus

Immunohistochemistry.text: Positive for CK-PAN (AE1/AE3), EMA/MUC1, vimentin, calretinin, Podoplanin(D2-40), CK5/CK6, thrombomodulin, mesothelin, WT1
Negative for CEA, TAG72, CD15, EPCAM/BER-EP4/CD326, desmin (frequent)

Adenocarcinoma of Rete Testis/Epididymis.text: More striking nuclear pleomorphism, significant desmoplasia, transition from rete testis epithelium
Positive for pax-8, negative for calretinin, Podoplanin (D2-40), or CK5/CK6

Metastatic Carcinoma.text: Clinical history of carcinoma elsewhere, usually greater cytologic atypia

Embryonal Carcinoma.text: Marked cytologic anaplasia, intratesticular mass, younger age
Positive for CD30 (BerH2), PLAP, Podoplanin (D2-40), SALL4, and OCT3/OCT4

Primary or Metastatic Sarcoma vs. Sarcom.text: High-grade spindle cells with greater cytologic atypia
Epicenter in spermatic cord; history of sarcoma elsewhere

Papillary Serous (Müllerian) Carcinoma o.text: Morphologically, may be very similar with histology of mesothelioma
Positive for WT1, p16, CD15, CA125, CEA; usually negative for calretinin, podoplanin (D2-40), or CK5/CK6

Adenomatoid Tumor.text: Often asymptomatic, small size and well circumscribed, commonly seen in epididymis
Bland cytologic features, no necrosis, no or few mitoses

Mesothelial Hyperplasia.text: Overall less cytologic atypia and lack of architectural complexity and true invasion
May be extremely difficult to distinguish from mesothelioma in small biopsy
Desmin is more frequently positive in mesothelial hyperplasia than mesothelioma

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Tubulopapillary, papillary, biphasic, or rarely sarcomatous tumor with epicenter in tunica vaginalis

Terminology.text: Malignant neoplasm showing adipocytic differentiation

Clinical Issues.text: Rare, but is most common sarcoma in paratesticular tissue in adults
Range: 41-87 yr (average: 63 yr)
Large scrotal mass
Surgical resection is usually curative
Unfavorable with dedifferentiation with metastasis

Macroscopic.text: Soft, homogeneous, multilobular, yellow-to-ivory mass
Fleshy white/tan-to-tan/gray firm areas with hemorrhage or necrosis

Microscopic.text: Mature adipose tissue of variable cellularity and fibrous tissue
Marked variation in adipocyte size and shape
Atypical cells with large, hyperchromatic nuclei
Lipoblasts with multivacuolated or univacuolated cytoplasm may be present
Dedifferentiated components, such as high-grade pleomorphic sarcoma or heterologous sarcoma components

Ancillary Tests.text: Positive for S100, CDK4, MDM2, p16

Definitions.text: Malignant neoplasm showing adipocytic differentiation

Incidence.text: Rare but is most common sarcoma in paratesticular tissue in adults

Presentation.text: Large scrotal mass
Usually involves spermatic cord, testicular tunica, or epididymis

Surgical approaches.text: Surgical resection is usually curative

Prognosis.text: Favorable with complete excision
Unfavorable with dedifferentiation with metastasis
Local recurrence may occur

General Features.text: Large hyperechoic mass by ultrasonography
CT and MR more specific as may detect fat component
Soft, homogeneous multilobular yellow-to-tan mass
May be mistaken for lipoma except for its large size and fibrous bands
Fleshy white-to-tan/gray firm areas with hemorrhage or necrosis indicate dedifferentiation

Histologic Features.text: Mature adipose tissue of variable cellularity with variable fibrous bands
Marked variation in adipocyte size and shape
Lipoblasts should be present but may be few in numbers
Atypical cells with large, hyperchromatic nuclei
Dedifferentiated components, such as high-grade pleomorphic sarcoma or heterologous sarcoma components
May have areas of low-grade leiomyosarcomatous dedifferentiation, which does not affect prognosis
Myxoid variant of liposarcoma has rarely been associated

Predominant Cell/Compartment Type.text: Mature adipose tissue and atypical pleomorphic nonlipogenic cells in dedifferentiated liposarcoma

Immunohistochemistry.text: Positive for S100, CDK4, MDM2, p16
Negative for HMB-45, actin-sm, desmin, MYOD1, or myogenin

Lipoma.text: Uniform adipocytes with no irregular fibrous bands or atypical cells (lipoblasts)

Adenomatoid Tumor.text: Cytoplasmic vacuoles rather than true lipogenic differentiation

Sclerosing Lipogranuloma.text: Histiocytes, giant cells, and granulomatous reaction due to exogenous lipid
Abundant inflammatory cells and absent lipoblasts

Rhabdomyosarcoma.text: Occurs in children or young adults
Composed of primitive cells and rhabdomyoblasts

Leiomyoma or Leiomyosarcoma.text: Uniform spindle cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm
Strong and uniformly positive for SMA and desmin

High-Grade Undifferentiated Sarcoma (Mal.text: Lack of typical areas of well-differentiated liposarcoma
No prior history of well-differentiated liposarcoma

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Presence of well-differentiated adipocytic mass-forming lesion in inguinal canal warrants serious consideration for liposarcoma

Terminology.text: Malignant neoplasm with skeletal muscle differentiation that recapitulates embryogenesis of skeletal muscle and encompasses spindle cell and anaplastic variants

Clinical Issues.text: Range: 7-36 years
Paratesticular location is one of the more common sites of rhabdomyosarcoma (4% of all)

Macroscopic.text: Well-circumscribed, large paratesticular mass (average: 4-6 cm)
Often multinodular with gelatinous, gray-white cut surface

Microscopic.text: Mixture of primitive and variable proportion of well-differentiated rhabdomyosarcomatous component
Alternating cellular and less cellular myxoid areas (embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma, not otherwise specified)
Spindle cells with fascicular pattern, mimicking leiomyosarcoma (spindle leiomyomatous rhabdomyosarcoma)
Primitive cells (blue cells) with small, round to oval, hyperchromatic cells or spindle cells
Differentiating rhabdomyosarcoma cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm, fibrillary material, or cross striations

Ancillary Tests.text: Positive for desmin, actin-HHF-35, myoglobin, MYOD1, myogenin, and vimentin

Synonyms.text: Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma, not otherwise specified (NOS); spindle leiomyomatous rhabdomyosarcoma

Definitions.text: Malignant neoplasm with skeletal muscle differentiation that recapitulates embryogenesis of skeletal muscle and encompasses spindle cell and anaplastic variants

Incidence.text: Most common sarcoma in children
Paratesticular location is one of more common sites of rhabdomyosarcoma (4% of all)

Presentation.text: Paratesticular mass in young patients
Gradual enlargement of scrotal sac with no acute onset symptoms
Transillumination may be positive when lesion is associated with hydrocele
May spread to paraaortic or paracaval lymph nodes and to bone and lung

Treatment.text: Usually multimodal, surgical resection ± radiotherapy or chemotherapy

Prognosis.text: Favorable prognosis in general with surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy

Prognosis associated with histologic type, age, tumor size and stage, and adequacy of resectionEmbryonal, NOS, and spindle cell variants have excellent prognosis compared to anaplastic variantAlveolar and pleomorphic types generally have poor prognosis (pleomorphic type occurs in adults)Paratesticular rhabdomyosarcoma has significantly better prognosis than tumors occurring elsewhere in genitourinary tract because of early detectionPatients > 10 years of age and tumors > 5 cm have worse prognosis
sub_points: Embryonal, NOS, and spindle cell variants have excellent prognosis compared to anaplastic variant
Alveolar and pleomorphic types generally have poor prognosis (pleomorphic type occurs in adults)
Paratesticular rhabdomyosarcoma has significantly better prognosis than tumors occurring elsewhere in genitourinary tract because of early detection
Patients > 10 years of age and tumors > 5 cm have worse prognosis

General Features.text: Well-circumscribed paratesticular mass
Often multinodular with gelatinous, gray-white cut surface
Patchy areas of necrosis, hemorrhage, or cystic change may be seen

Histologic Features.text: Mixture of primitive and variable proportion of well-differentiated rhabdomyosarcomatous component
Alternating cellular and less cellular myxoid areas (embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma, NOS)
Spindle cells with fascicular pattern, mimicking leiomyosarcoma (spindle leiomyomatous rhabdomyosarcoma)
Primitive cells (blue cells) with small, round to oval, hyperchromatic cells or spindle cells
Differentiating rhabdomyosarcoma cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm, fibrillary material, or cross striations
Diffuse anaplasia with atypical mitoses (anaplastic variant of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma) may be seen
Alveolar, pleomorphic, or botryoid types of rhabdomyosarcoma are extremely rare in paratesticular area

Predominant Pattern/Injury Type.text: Myxoid spindle cell tumor with cellular and less cellular areas or interlacing fascicles of spindle cells

Predominant Cell/Compartment Type.text: Small round or spindle cells with dense eosinophilic cytoplasm (rhabdomyoblasts) and may show cross striation

Immunohistochemistry.text: Positive for desmin, actin-HHF-35, myoglobin, MYOD1, myogenin, and vimentin
Negative for S100, cytokeratin, LCA

Leiomyosarcoma.text: Uniform fascicular spindle cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm
Diffusely positive for actin-sm and desmin; negative for myoglobin, MYOD1, and myogenin

Dedifferentiated Liposarcoma.text: History of or current well-differentiated liposarcoma (atypical lipomatous tumor)
Tumor with areas of atypical lipomatous component

Malignant Lymphoma/Leukemia.text: Relatively uniform tumor cells and lack of cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, lack of myxoid background
Primarily interstitial testicular involvement with paratesticular extension

Other Small Blue Cell Tumors.text: Uniform small cell proliferation with lack of spindle cells and cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm
Lack alternating cellular and myxoid areas
Negative for desmin, myoglobin, MYOD1, and myogenin

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Myxoid spindle cell tumor with cellular and less cellular areas containing pink (rhabdomyoblastic) cells; interlacing fascicles with spindle cells resembling leiomyosarcoma

Terminology.text: Flat urothelial lesion composed of cytologically malignant cells with high-grade atypia

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Multiple predisposing environmental factors are known

Clinical Issues.text: Most common in men, 6th-7th decades
Multifocality common, including upper urinary tract involvement
If de novo, may progress to invasive carcinoma
Often associated with high-grade papillary &/or invasive urothelial carcinoma

Microscopic.text: Disordered urothelium with loss of polarity to basement membrane
Unequivocal high-grade cytologic atypia may involving partial- or full-thickness surface lesion
Marked nucleomegaly is typical
Nuclear hyperchromasia with coarse condensed chromatin is typical
Spectrum of atypia and growth patterns exists

Ancillary Tests.text: CK20, AMACR, CD44, and p53 immunohistochemistry may be useful in distinction from nonneoplastic reactive atypiaDiffuse cytoplasmic staining for CK20 and AMACR in atypical cells is common in carcinoma in situ (CIS)Membranous CD44 staining is common in benign reactive lesions
sub_points: Diffuse cytoplasmic staining for CK20 and AMACR in atypical cells is common in carcinoma in situ (CIS)
Membranous CD44 staining is common in benign reactive lesions

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Urothelial atypia of unknown significance and dysplasia

Diagnostic Checklist.text: Disordered urothelium containing cells with unequivocal atypia

Synonyms.text: UCIS is only appropriate term for this lesion under WHO classification

Definitions.text: Flat, nonpapillary urothelial lesion composed of cytologically malignant cells
Variable thickness, disordered urothelium

Environmental Exposure.text: Tobacco smoking, analgesic abuse, and arylamine compounds are known predisposing factors

Molecular Pathogenesis.text: Contemporary sequencing studies identify recurrent mutations in carcinoma in situ (CIS)TERTpromoter mutation in ~ 50% of casesMutation in cell cycle genes, such asTP53,MDM2,CCND1,CDKN1A,CDKN2A,CCNE1, andFBXW7in > 70% of casesMutations in chromatin-modifying factors, such asARID1A,KDM6A,CREBBP, andEP300in~ 60-70% of casesMutations in DNA damage response genes, such asBRCA2,ATM,BRCA1, andERCC2in ~ 60% of casesMutations in PI3K/MAPK genes, such asERBB2(HER2),FGFR1,PIK3CA,EGFR,RAF1, andNF1in ~ 30-40% of cases
sub_points: TERTpromoter mutation in ~ 50% of cases
Mutation in cell cycle genes, such asTP53,MDM2,CCND1,CDKN1A,CDKN2A,CCNE1, andFBXW7in > 70% of cases
Mutations in chromatin-modifying factors, such asARID1A,KDM6A,CREBBP, andEP300in~ 60-70% of cases
Mutations in DNA damage response genes, such asBRCA2,ATM,BRCA1, andERCC2in ~ 60% of cases
Mutations in PI3K/MAPK genes, such asERBB2(HER2),FGFR1,PIK3CA,EGFR,RAF1, andNF1in ~ 30-40% of cases

Incidence.text: Primary (de novo) CIS is rare (< 3% of all urothelial neoplasms)
Secondary CIS is more commonly (45-65%) detected adjacent or subsequent to high-grade papillary and invasive urothelial carcinoma

Age.text: Most typically seen in men in 6th or 7th decade

Presentation.text: Nonspecific clinical features, irritative voiding symptoms, frequency, hematuria

Treatment.text: Different forms of intravesical therapyBCG instillation is standard treatment
sub_points: BCG instillation is standard treatment

Treatment.text: Cystectomy is common treatment for patients refractory to intravesical therapy

Prognosis.text: Behavior of CIS is somewhat unpredictable~ 50% of patients progress to invasion in 5 yearsPrimary (de novo) CIS seems to have lower progression rate than secondary or concomitant CIS
sub_points: ~ 50% of patients progress to invasion in 5 years
Primary (de novo) CIS seems to have lower progression rate than secondary or concomitant CIS

General Features.text: Cystoscopic appearance may range from normal to erythematous, edematous, or erosive
Multifocality is commonEither within urinary bladder &/or upper urinary tract
sub_points: Either within urinary bladder &/or upper urinary tract

Histologic Features.text: Cytologic disorder of urothelium; loss of polarization and crowding

Unequivocal high-grade cytologic atypia may involve either full or partial thickness of urotheliumNuclear pleomorphism and anaplasia may be obviousSpectrum of cytologic atypia existsMarked nucleomegaly is typical (3-6x size of normal lymphocyte nucleus)Coarse, condensed nuclear chromatin is typicalProminent nucleoli, multiple nucleoli, nucleolar pleomorphismMitoses are usually frequent, with atypical forms, but may be variableDyscohesion cohesion may be prominent, sloughing or clinging patternsSome examples have abundant eosinophilic cytoplasmAngioplasia/capillary proliferation induced in underlying superficial lamina propria
sub_points: Nuclear pleomorphism and anaplasia may be obvious

Spectrum of cytologic atypia existsMarked nucleomegaly is typical (3-6x size of normal lymphocyte nucleus)Coarse, condensed nuclear chromatin is typicalProminent nucleoli, multiple nucleoli, nucleolar pleomorphismMitoses are usually frequent, with atypical forms, but may be variableDyscohesion cohesion may be prominent, sloughing or clinging patternsSome examples have abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm

Prominent nucleoli, multiple nucleoli, nucleolar pleomorphism

Some examples have abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm

Atypia and dysplasia show atypia believed to be neoplastic but deemed insufficient for CIS diagnosisDysplasia term used in different ways by experts, not reproducible; most often in setting of low-grade papillary urothelial carcinomaDysplasia should be used when changes are beyond reactive changes, but falling short of CISMost experts use term atypia with comments specifying diagnostic considerations and recommendationsWe caution against diagnosis of de novo dysplasia (no known bladder cancer)

AUS and Urothelial Dysplasia.text: Most important to have appropriate minimal diagnostic threshold for CIS

Reactive Urothelial Atypia.text: Intraurothelial &/or suburothelial inflammation is usually prominent
Although there is nuclear enlargement, it is usuallyuniformUsually < 3x size of normal lymphocyte nucleus
sub_points: Usually < 3x size of normal lymphocyte nucleus

Reactive Urothelial Atypia.text: Nucleoli are common, prominent, and chromatin evenly dispersed
Mitosis is usually increased, but atypical forms are absent

Radiation-/Chemotherapy-Related Atypia.text: Cells often have intracytoplasmic and nuclear vacuolization
Radiation-induced changes evident in underlying tissueStromal hemorrhage, vasculopathy, and thrombosisAtypical hyperchromatic stromal fibroblasts
sub_points: Stromal hemorrhage, vasculopathy, and thrombosis
Atypical hyperchromatic stromal fibroblasts

Intravesical BCG or Mitomycin-Associated.text: Urothelial denudation and inflammation; partial squamous metaplasis is common
Nuclear enlargement and nucleoli are common

Clinically Relevant Pathologic Features.text: Multifocality and microinvasion

Gross or microscopic hematuria

Diagnosis to avoid in individuals with history of carcinoma

Terminology.text: Urothelial carcinoma invading beyond basement membrane

It identified different underlying oncogenic mechanisms, infiltration by immune and stromal cells, histologic characteristics, and clinical outcome

These subtypes were labeled luminal papillary, luminal nonspecified, luminal unstable, stroma rich, basal/squamous and NE-likethat were identified in 24%, 8%, 15%, 15%, 35%, and 3% of tumors, respectively

Tumor cells typically range from flat to cuboidal
Hobnail pattern of cells commonly seen
Mixed clear and eosinophilic cytoplasm
Papillae may have densely hyalinized cores
Cytologic atypia usually moderate to severe, but areas with low-grade features may be present
Mitotic figures are frequent
Tumor invasion readily identified but may be difficult to assess in small or superficial biopsies
Tumor may have mixed histology with invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma

Ancillary Tests.text: Positive for CK7, CEA, and CA125; occasionally for CK20
MIB-1 proliferation index is high
Also expresses napsin, PAX8, and AMACR

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Secondary involvement from gynecologic tract CCA

Diagnostic Checklist.text: Not all CCAs have clear cell features
Multitude of patterns is typically the rule in these tumors
CCA should be considered when considering large nephrogenic adenoma or those with marked atypia
Metastasis/extension from adjacent primaries should be ruled out

Site.text: Urinary bladder most common site in genitourinary tract
